instruction: Give me an underline exercise for a student learning German. It should be an exercise on pronunciation of ch.
response:
Find and underline the words containing "ch," which is pronounced like the "h" in "huge".\\

Heute Morgen bin ich um elf aufgewacht. Ich hatte Pech, denn ich habe den Wecker nicht gehört. Heute werde ich einfach zuHause bleiben. Vielleicht kann ich auch einen Film sehen. Es ist in Ordnung, wenn man sich ein bisschen von allem erholen will. Morgen ist wieder ein neuer Tag. Mein Vater holt mich ab und wir werden in einen Wald voller Fichten gehen. Vielleicht werden wir auch meine Schwester mitnehmen.

instruction: Give me a planning exercise for a 6th grade student learning computer science. It should be an exercise on surveys.

instruction: Give me a combination of a reading exercise and a comprehension exercise for a student learning German. It should have a subsection for answers. It should be an exercise involving a separate translation.
response:
Es war einmal ein armer Mann, der in einem Dorf wohnte. Dieser Mann war sehr arm, aber er besaß ein Pferd, das so exquisit war, das selbst Könige es ihm abkaufen wollten-  und das zu jedem Preis. Doch der Mann lehnte immer wieder ab. Plötzlich eines Morgens, stellte er fest, dass das Pferd verschwunden war. Alle Menschen aus dem Dorf versammelten um ihr Mitgefühl auszudrücken.\\

Sie sagten: "Oh, was für ein Unglück, was hättest du für ein Vermögen mit diesem Pferd verdienen können und man hat dir so viel dafür geboten! Aber du warst zu dickköpfig und zu dumm. Jetzt ist das Pferd weg. "\\

Aber der alte Mann lachte nur und sagte: "Ach redet doch keinen Unsinn: "Alles was man darüber sagen kann, ist, dass das Pferd jetzt nicht mehr in seinem Stall ist. Lass die Zukunft kommen und uns zeigen was passiert"\\

Nach wenigen Tagen kehrte das Pferd plötzlich zurück in seinen Stall. Nicht nur das, es brachte eine ganze Herde wilder Pferde aus dem Wald mit. Und wieder versammelte sich das ganze Dorf und sie sagten: "Unglaublich, der alte Mann hatte Recht sein Pferd ist tatsächlich zurückgekommen, und es hat auch noch ein ganzes dutzend toller Pferde mitgebracht. Jetzt kann er so viel Geld verdienen, wie er will." Und sie gingen zu dem alten Mann und sagten: "Oh es tut uns Leid wir konnten das ja nicht voraussehen und die Wege Gottes verstehen, aber du bist unglaublich. Du hast es wohl irgendwie geahnt. Vielleicht kannst du sogar die Zukunft voraussehen."\\

"So ein Quatsch." sagte der alte Mann nur. "Ich weiß nur, eins: Nämlich, dass das Pferd mit einer ganzen Herde Pferde zurückgekommen ist und was morgen geschehen wird, das weiß nur der liebe Gott."\\

Und schon ein paar Tage später geschah es, das der einzige Sohn des Mannes, der die neuen Pferde zureiten wollte, dabei vom Pferd fiel. Er brach sich dabei seine Beine so schwer, das er fortan wohl nicht mehr würde richtig laufen können. Die Menschen kamen wieder zu dem alten Mann und sagten: "Du hast recht gehabt. Man weiß nie. Die Sache mit den Pferden hat sich als ein Fluch erwiesen. Da wäre es besser gewesen, wären die Pferde überhaupt gar nicht erst gekommen. Nun wird dein Sohn für sein ganzes Leben lang verkrüppelt sein.\\

Aber der alte Mann sagte wieder nur: "Nicht so voreilig. Wartet ab! Man wird sehen was geschieht. Man kann nämlich nur eines darüber sagen, nämlich, dass mein Sohn sich die Beine gebrochen hat. Das ist alles."\\

Einige Wochen später ergab es sich das in dem Land ein Krieg ausbrach und alle die jungen Männer des Dorfes von der Regierung zwangsweise eingezogen wurden. Nur der Sohn des alten Mannes durfte zu Hause bleiben, weil er für den Krieg untauglich war.\\

Und wieder versammelten sich alle Menschen des Dorfes und klagten: "Unsere Söhne sind fort und du hast wenigstens noch deinen Sohn. Er mag zwar seine Beine gebrochen haben, aber er ist bei dir. Unsere Söhne sind fort und der Feind ist vielleicht viel mächtiger. Wahrscheinlich werden sie alle sterben. Jetzt werden wir niemanden haben, der sich im Alter um uns kümmert. Aber du hast ja noch deinen Sohn. Er wird bestimmt wieder gesund.\\

Doch der alte Mann sagte wieder nur: "Man kann darüber nur eins sagen: Eure Söhne wurden eingezogen. Mein Sohn ist hier geblieben. Daraus folgt jedoch gar nichts.\\

\begin{enumerate}
\item Wie viele Pferde hatte der Mann am Anfang?
\item Mit wem lebte der Mann?
\item Wer kam immer zu dem Mann, um seine Situation zu beurteilen?
\item Was geschah als das Pferd wieder kam?
\item Was passierte mit dem Sohn des Mannes?
\item Was sagen die Bewohner des Dorfes über die Pferde, nachdem sich der Sohn verletzt hat?
    \begin{enumerate}
    \item dass es sich als ein Segen erwiesen hat
    \item dass es sich als ein Fluch erwiesen hat
    \item es ist einfach sein Schicksal
    \end{enumerate}
\item Wie viele Pferde kamen mit dem Pferd des Mannes zurück?
    \begin{enumerate}
    \item zwei
    \item zehn
    \item ein dutzend
    \end{enumerate}
\item Was hat der Sohn gebrochen als er vom Pferd fiel?
    \begin{enumerate}
    \item die Arme
    \item beide Beine
    \item einen Finger
    \end{enumerate}
\item Was sagen die Bewohner, nachdem das Pferd wieder zurück ist?
    \begin{enumerate}
    \item es ist ein magisches Pferd
    \item die Pferde sind wunderschön
    \item der Mann kann die Zukunft voraussehen
    \end{enumerate}
\item Wie endet die Geschichte?
    \begin{enumerate}
    \item die Bewohner klauen das Pferd von dem Mann
    \item die Söhne der Bewohner müssen in den Krieg, während der Sohn des Mannes es nicht muss
    \item der Mann zieht mit seinem Sohn in ein anderes Dorf und schenkt die Pferde den Bewohnern des Dorfes
    \end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Translation}
Once upon a time, there was a poor man who lived in a village. This man was very poor, but he owned a horse so exquisite that even kings wanted to buy it from him—at any price. Yet, the man repeatedly refused. One morning, he suddenly discovered that the horse was gone. All the villagers gathered to express their sympathy.\\

They said: “Oh, what bad luck! You could have earned a fortune with that horse, and so many had offered you so much for it! But you were too stubborn and too foolish. Now the horse is gone.”\\

But the old man just laughed and said: “Oh, stop talking nonsense. All that can be said about this is that the horse is no longer in its stable. Let the future come and show us what will happen.”\\

A few days later, the horse suddenly returned to its stable. Not only that, but it brought with it an entire herd of wild horses from the forest. Once again, the whole village gathered, and they said: “Unbelievable! The old man was right—his horse actually came back, and it even brought a dozen fine horses with it. Now he can earn as much money as he wants.” They went to the old man and said: “Oh, we are sorry; we could not foresee this or understand God’s ways. But you are incredible. You must have had some inkling. Maybe you can even see the future.”\\

“Nonsense,” said the old man. “I only know one thing: the horse came back with a whole herd of horses. What will happen tomorrow is known only to God.”\\

And just a few days later, it happened that the man’s only son, who was trying to tame the new horses, fell off one of them. He broke his legs so badly that he would likely never be able to walk properly again. The people came to the old man once more and said: “You were right. One never knows. This business with the horses turned out to be a curse. It would have been better if the horses had never come at all. Now your son will be crippled for the rest of his life.”\\

But the old man again said: “Don’t be so quick to judge. Wait and see! All that can be said is that my son broke his legs. That’s all.”\\

A few weeks later, a war broke out in the land, and all the young men of the village were forcibly conscripted by the government. Only the old man’s son was allowed to stay home because he was unfit for war.\\

Once again, all the villagers gathered and lamented: “Our sons are gone, but at least you still have your son. He may have broken his legs, but he is here with you. Our sons are gone, and the enemy may be far more powerful. They will probably all die. Now we will have no one to care for us in our old age. But you still have your son. He will surely recover.”\\

But the old man once again said: “There is only one thing that can be said: your sons were conscripted. My son stayed here. That’s all. Nothing follows from this.”\\

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Der Mann hatte ein Pferd.
\item Mit seinem Sohn.
\item Die Bewohner aus dem Dorf.
\item Das Pferd kam wieder mit einem Dutzend anderer Pferde.
\item Der Sohn des Mannes fiel vom Pferd.
\item 2
\item 3
\item 2
\item 3
\item 2
\end{enumerate}

Give me a q&a exercise for a student learning Spanish. It should have a subsection for answers. It should be an exercise on responding to questions.
response:
Responde las preguntas siguiendo el ejemplo.  
Ejemplo: ¿Guardo la leche en el refri? (Tú). Sí, guárdala.  
¿Guardo las manzanas en el refri? (Usted). Sí, guárdelas.  

\begin{enumerate}
    \item ¿Abro la ventana de tu habitación? (Tú)

instruction: Give me a combination of an activity, a group discussion, and an experiment for a 5th grade student learning science. It should have a subsection for materials. It should be an exercise on mirrors. It should be an exercise on light redirection.
response:
\begin{itemize}
\item Use the mirror to create as many different effects as you can.
\item Switch on the torch. Using a mirror, you can make the light from your torch beam shine on a wall.
\item When you have succeeded, draw a diagram of how you did it. Use arrows to show the direction and path of the light from its source to the mirror, and from the mirror to the wall.
\item Collect two shiny objects and take them outside into the sunlight.
\item Try using the shiny objects to re-direct the sunlight onto a wall or other shaded surface. How did you do it?
\item Back in class, draw a diagram of what you did with the shiny objects.
\item Discuss your results with your group.
\item Try to explain how the light was re-directed by the mirror and the shiny objects.
\item Compare the three surfaces. What is similar about all of them?
\item Share your results and explanations with the class.
\end{itemize}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
\item A mirror
\item A torch
\item A variety of shiny objects
\end{itemize}

instruction: Give me a reading exercise for a student learning Dutch. It should be an exercise on reading advertisements. It should be a with Answer.
response:
Read the advertisement for the treintaxi and answer the questions in Dutch.\\

\emph{DOE EENS MAKKELIJK. NEEM DE TREINTAXI.}\\
De Treintaxi brengt u op een comfortabele manier van en naar het NS-station.\\
U deelt de Treintaxi met andere passagiers.\\
Een kaartje voor de Treintaxi kost €4,70.\\
U kunt dit op het station kopen.\\
U geeft uw kaartje aan de chauffeur.\\
U kunt een kaartje voor de taxi ook bij de chauffeur kopen, maar dan is het duurder.\\
De chauffeur wacht bij het station maximaal 10 minuten op andere passagiers.\\
De Treintaxi rijdt van en naar meer dan 30 stations.\\
De Treintaxi kan u dus ook ophalen en naar het station brengen.\\
Bel dan een half uur voor u wilt vertrekken naar de Treintaxi-centrale

\begin{enumerate}
\item Wat is het voordeel (advantage) van de treintaxi?
\item Waar koop je een kaartje voor de treintaxi?
\item Hoe lang wacht de chauffeur op andere passagiers?
\item Bij hoeveel stations staat een treintaxi?
\item Wat is het nadeel (disadvantage) als je een kaartje bij de chauffeur koopt?
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Het voordeel van de treintaxi is dat het u op een comfortabele manier van en naar het NS-station brengt.
\item Je koopt een kaartje voor de treintaxi op het station.
\item De chauffeur wacht maximaal
\item minuten op andere passagiers.
\item Een treintaxi staat bij meer dan
\item stations.
\item Het nadeel als je een kaartje bij de chauffeur koopt, is dat het duurder is.
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a reading exercise for a student learning Dutch. It should have a subsection for answers. It should be an exercise on holiday plans.
response:
Ludwien Wij Willen volgende maand een weekje op vakantie.\\
Gewoon in Nederland. Hebben jullie misschien zin om mee te gaan?\\
Jackie Ja, dat lijkt me erg leuk.\\
Ludwien We moeten wel goede afspraken maken.\\
Jackie Over wat we precies gaan doen, bedoel je?\\
Ludwien Nee, ik bedoel afspraken over wie wat gaat voorbereiden.\\
Jackie O, goed. Ik zal op het internet zoeken op de website van de VVV.\\
Ludwien Ik zal naar de ANWB gaan.\\

Answer the following questions in English.
\begin{enumerate}
\item When does Ludwien want to go on holiday and for how long?
\item Which word shows that Ludwien thinks a holiday in Holland is nothing special?
\item Is Jackie keen to come along with Ludwien and her family?
\item What does Ludwien want to ensure both Jackie and her are clear about?
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Ludwien wants to go on holiday next month for a week.
\item The word gewoon shows that Ludwien thinks a holiday in Holland is nothing special.
\item Yes, Jackie is keen to come along with Ludwien and her family.
\item Ludwien wants to ensure both Jackie and her are clear about who will prepare what.
\end{enumerate}

Give me a vocabulary exercise for a student learning Dutch. It should have a subsection for answers. It should be an exercise on saying goodbye in Dutch.
response:
There are various ways of saying goodbye in Dutch:\\
You can use tot zo and tot straks, which both mean see you in a little while.\\
If two individuals did not know when they would meet again, they could say tot ziens.\\
Similarly, if they knew they would meet again in the evening or the next morning, they could have said tot vanavond, tot morgen or tot dan (see you then).

\begin{enumerate}
\item What would they have said if they were going to meet again this afternoon?
\item And what would they have said if they were going to meet again on Sunday?
\item And on Wednesday?
\item And on Tuesday?
\item And what if they were going to meet again next week?
\item And next month?
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Tot straks.
\item Tot zondag.
\item Tot woensdag.
\item Tot dinsdag.
\item Tot volgende week.
\item Tot volgende maand.
\end{enumerate}

\item Du machst \_\_\_\_\_\_ein ganz schlechtes Gewissen.
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a fill-in-the-blanks exercise for a student learning German. It should be an exercise on the subjunctive 1 form.
response:
Fill the spaces with the right subjunctive 1 form.

\begin{enumerate}
\item - er \_\_\_\_\_ (haben) Hunger.
\item - er \_\_\_\_\_ (sein) gestern sehr spät nach Hause gekommen.
\item - Marcus und Franko \_\_\_\_\_\_ (sein) heute schon um da gewesen.
\item - er \_\_\_\_\_(kommen) heute.
\item - du \_\_\_\_\_ (sein) zuhause.
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a true-false exercise for a 4th grade student learning science. It should be an exercise on sound. It should be an exercise on music.
response: You can change the pitch of sounds to make music. True / False

instruction: Give me a true-false exercise for a 5th grade student learning social studies. It should be an exercise on hemispheres.
response:
Copy the true statement:
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item The Arabian Peninsula is in the northern hemisphere.  
\item The Arabian Peninsula is in the southern hemisphere.  
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a true-false exercise for a 4th grade student learning science. It should be an exercise on identification keys.
response:
True or false?
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item We can use identification keys to help us name unfamiliar creatures. True / False
\item Identification keys can be simple or complex. True / False
\item We can only use identification keys to identify plants. True / False
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a true-false exercise for a 3rd grade student learning science. It should be an exercise on life forces. It should be a with Answer. It should be an exercise on animal movement.
Give me a true-false exercise for a 5th grade student learning science. It should be an exercise on shadows. It should be a with Answer. It should be an exercise on shadow puppets.
Give me a true-false exercise for a 5th grade student learning science. It should be an exercise on flowering plants. It should be an exercise on life cycle.
response:
Decide whether the following statements are true or false.
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item There are two stages in the life cycle of a flowering plant.
\item The life cycle is a continuous process.
\item Some flowering plants produce seeds with flesh.
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a true-false exercise for a 4th grade student learning science. It should be an exercise on melting and freezing. It should be an exercise on ice.
response: Ice melts at 100°C. True or False?

instruction: Give me a true-false exercise for a 4th grade student learning science. It should be an exercise on muscles and skeletons. It should be an exercise on joints.
response:
True or false?
\begin{enumerate}
\item Muscles are attached to bones.
\item Bones can move on their own.
\item Elbows and knees are examples of joints.
\item We use our jaw muscles for talking.
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a true-false exercise for a 6th grade student learning science. It should be an exercise on caring for the environment. It should be a with Answer. It should be an exercise on endangered species.
Give me a group activity for a 4th grade student learning social studies. It should be an exercise on values. It should be an activity on family life.
response: Work in a group to prepare some questions to ask your parents about values that they were taught as children and the things they think are different about family life today.

instruction: Give me a group activity for a 4th grade student learning social studies. It should be an activity on designing a public information campaign.
response: Work in a group to design a public information campaign on a subject of your choice.

instruction: Give me a group activity for a 2nd grade student learning social studies. It should be an exercise on identifying commonly touched items in class.
response: Work in a group to make a list of all the things in class that lots of people touch.

instruction: Give me a group activity for a 3rd grade student learning history. It should be an exercise on tasks in an Iron Age village.
response: Work in a group. Take turns to describe one task carried out by a man, woman or child in an Iron Age village. Score one point for each task you name. Miss a go if you cannot name a task.

instruction: Give me a group activity for a 3rd grade student learning social studies. It should be an exercise on rules. It should be an activity on group membership.
response: Work in a group to make a list of some groups to which you belong where there are definite rules. Write about who makes the rules and what the rules are for.

instruction: Give me a group activity for a 6th grade student learning social studies. It should be an exercise on imports and exports. It should be an activity on food security.
response: Work in a group to identify and describe imports and exports in your country. Explain what your findings show, especially in respect of food security.

instruction: Give me a group activity for a 3rd grade student learning history. It should be an exercise on interpreting cave paintings.
response:
In a group, discuss what these images from cave paintings might tell us about life in the Stone Age:  
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item groups of running animals followed by humans holding weapons
\item a group of people gathered together in a circle
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a group activity for a 3rd grade student learning social studies. It should be an exercise on career.
response: Work in a group to identify all the different jobs that people do in your community.

instruction: Give me a group activity for a 6th grade student learning social studies. It should be an exercise on inequality. It should be an activity on global food distribution.
response: Work in a group to suggest some ideas that would mean that everyone in the world had enough to eat.

instruction: Give me a group activity for a 6th grade student learning social studies. It should be an exercise on issues affecting children and young people.
response: Work in a group to identify issues which you feel affect children and young people in particular and suggest ways they could be involved in these areas.

instruction: Give me a group activity for a 4th grade student learning social studies. It should be an exercise on living up to Islamic values. It should be an activity on tolerance and respect.
response: Work in a group to make a list of guidelines that will help people to live up to the Islamic values of tolerance and respect.

instruction: Give me a group activity for a 4th grade student learning social studies. It should be an exercise on the needs of people in the classroom.
response: Work in a group to discuss people's needs in the classroom. Describe the sort of class behaviour that will make sure those needs are met.

instruction: Give me a combination of a group activity and a research exercise for a 4th grade student learning history. It should be an exercise on achievements of important figures from Ancient Greece.
response: Work in a group to research the achievements of an important person from Ancient Greece such as Herodotus, Homer, Aristotle, Plato, Socrates or Pythagoras.

instruction: Give me a combination of a group activity and a drawing exercise for a 3rd grade student learning history. It should be an exercise on map drawing.
response: In a group, draw a map of a Sumerian city-state. Add labels to show what is valuable and why the city-state might be attacked.

instruction: Give me a combination of a group activity and a writing exercise for a 6th grade student learning computer science. It should be an exercise on writing algorithms.
Give me a combination of a group activity and a research exercise for a 6th grade student learning history. It should be an exercise on city development over time.
response:
Work with a friend or in a small group to carry out research into one of the following cities to find out how it has developed over time.  
\begin{itemize}
\item New York City, USA
\item Tokyo, Japan  
\item Paris, France  
\item Nairobi, Kenya  
\item Rio de Janeiro, Brazil  
\item Cairo, Egypt  
\end{itemize}

instruction: Give me a combination of a group activity and a research exercise for a 5th grade student learning social studies. It should be an exercise on advertising. It should be an activity on analyzing advertisements.
response: Work in a group to research and analyse some current advertisements.

instruction: Give me a combination of a research exercise and a group activity for a 5th grade student learning social studies. It should be an exercise on historical civilizations.
response: Work in a group to find out about a civilisation from history. Find out where the civilisation was founded, how long it lasted, and identify two of its major achievements.

instruction: Give me a combination of a group activity, a research exercise, and a long answer exercise for a 4th grade student learning history. It should be an exercise on buildings inspired by Egyptian architecture.
response: In a group, research three buildings that were inspired by Egyptian architecture. Write about each building, including where it is.

instruction: Give me a combination of a group activity and a writing exercise for a 4th grade student learning social studies. It should be an exercise on ancient trade.
response: Work in a group to make a fact sheet about how ancient trade made people think of new inventions or ways of doing things.

instruction: Give me a combination of a group activity and a research exercise for a 4th grade student learning social studies. It should be an exercise on recent public information campaigns.
response: Work in a group to find out about some recent public information campaigns in your country.

instruction: Give me a combination of a group activity and a writing exercise for a 2nd grade student learning social studies. It should be an exercise on keeping safe in the home.
response: Work in a group and write some rules you would have about keeping safe in the home.

instruction: Give me a translation exercise for a student learning French. It should be an exercise on could/would/should. It should be a with Answer.
response:
Could, would ou should? Traduire en anglais les phrases suivantes.
\begin{enumerate}
    \item Pourrais-tu ouvrir la porte?
    \item À cette heure, il devrait être à la maison.
    \item Ils n'ont pas pu avoir de billets.
    \item Voudriez-vous bien participer à ce projet?
    \item Je suis venu le chercher; il n'a pas voulu venir avec moi.
    \item Si tu étais moins égoïste, tu aurais plus d'amis.
    \item Voudrais-tu bien me montrer comment ça fonctionne?
    \item Il n'a pas pu partir à temps.
    \item Lorsque nous étions enfants, nous allions à la mer tous les étés.
    \item Il devrait réfléchir avant de parler.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Could you open the door?
\item At that time, he should be home.
\item They could not get tickets.
\item Would you like to participate in this project?
\item I came to pick him up. He would not come with me.
\item If you were not so selfish, you would have more friends.
\item Would you be willing to show me how it works?
\item He could not leave in time.
\item When we were children, we would go to the seashore every summer.
\item He should think before talking.
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a translation exercise for a student learning French. It should be an exercise on using the conditional tense. It should be a with Answer.
response:
Traduire les phrases suivantes en utilisant le conditionnel journalistique, présent ou passé.

\begin{enumerate}
    \item The prime minister reportedly went to China yesterday.
    \item The witness allegedly gave the police a different version.
    \item The cyclone reportedly killed two hundred people in this town.
    \item The director reportedly resigned.
    \item The storm has reportedly destroyed a hundred houses.
    \item Unemployment is reportedly going to decline next year.
    \item The health minister reportedly signed the reform.
    \item Penguins are reportedly unable to reproduce because of global warming.
    \item His new neighbor allegedly stole his car.
    \item A French actor reportedly bought a house in California last week.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}

\begin{enumerate}
    \item Le Premier Ministre serait allé en Chine hier.
    \item Le témoin aurait donné une version différente à la police.
    \item Le cyclone aurait tué deux cents personnes dans cette ville.
    \item Le directeur aurait démissionné.
    \item La tempête aurait détruit des centaines de maisons.
    \item Le chômage baisserait l'année prochaine.
    \item Le ministre de la Santé aurait signé la réforme.
    \item Les pingouins ne pourraient pas se reproduire en raison du réchauffement climatique.
    \item Son nouveau voisin aurait volé sa voiture.
    \item Un acteur français aurait acheté une maison en Californie la semaine dernière.
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a translation exercise for a student learning Spanish. It should be an exercise on translating from Spanish to English. It should be a with Answer.
response:
Translate from Spanish to English and vice versa.  

\begin{enumerate}
    \item Buenas tardes.
    \item How are you? (informal)
    \item Very well.
    \item No muy bien.
    \item And you? (formal)
    \item ¡Hasta pronto!
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
  \item Good evening.
  \item ¿Cómo estás?
  \item Muy bien.
  \item Not so good.
  \item ¿Y usted?
  \item See you soon!
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a translation exercise for a student learning French. It should be an exercise on translating numbers. It should be a with Answer.
response:
Traduire (en toutes lettres) les nombres suivants:
\begin{enumerate}
    \item two hundred twelve
    \item three hundred fifteen
    \item four hundred twenty
    \item five hundred thirty-one
    \item six hundred twenty-three
    \item seven hundred ninety
    \item eight hundred forty-eight
    \item nine hundred four
    \item six hundred forty-five
    \item one hundred one
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
    \item deux cent douze
    \item trois cent quinze
    \item quatre cent vingt
    \item cinq cent trente et un
    \item six cent vingt-trois
    \item sept cent quatre-vingt-dix
    \item huit cent quarante-huit
    \item neuf cent quatre
    \item six cent quarante-cinq
    \item cent un
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a translation exercise for a student learning French. It should be an exercise on translating possessive pronouns. It should be a with Answer.
response:
Traduire les pronoms possessifs entre parenthèses.
\begin{enumerate}
    \item Mes documents sont en anglais. (His)          sont en français.
    \item Ses parents viennent d'Écosse. (Mine)          viennent d'Irlande.
    \item Il n'a pas trouvé son acte de naissance. Voici (mine)          .
    \item Nous avons choisi notre itinéraire. Avez-vous choisi (yours)          ?
    \item Elle a fi ni son roman. As-tu fi ni (yours)          ?
    \item Ses idées sont étranges. Et (theirs)          aussi.
    \item Je suis vos conseils et je vous demande de suivre (ours)          .
    \item Mon blouson est en cuir marron et (hers)          est en cuir noir.
    \item Ton plat est trop épicé et (mine)          est trop salé.
    \item Mon neveu est trop âgé et (his)          est trop jeune pour ce spectacle.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Les siens
\item Les miens
\item le mien
\item le vôtre
\item le tien
\item les leurs
\item les nôtres
\item le sien
\item le mien
\item le sien
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a translation exercise for a student learning French. It should have a subsection for answers. It should be an exercise on using tu and inversion.
response:
Traduire en français les phrases suivantes en utilisant tu et l'inversion si nécessaire.

\begin{enumerate}
    \item Could you read this document?
    \item We should buy tickets for the concert.
    \item Valérie could help you!
    \item At that time, she could not go out very often.
    \item Could you send me a copy of that letter?
    \item I asked her to help me; she would not do it.
    \item Pascal would play the violin if he had more time.
    \item Marie could not tell him the truth.
    \item When we were kids, we would play for hours on the beach.
    \item Don't you think you should change your haircut?
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}

\begin{enumerate}
    \item Pourrais-tu lire ce document?
    \item Nous devrions acheter des billets pour le concert.
    \item Valérie pourrait t'aider!
    \item À cette époque-là, elle ne pouvait pas sortir souvent.
    \item Pourrais-tu m'envoyer un double de cette lettre?
    \item Je lui ai demandé de m'aider; elle n'a pas voulu.
    \item Pascal jouerait du violon s'il avait plus de temps.
    \item Marie n'a pas pu lui dire la vérité.
    \item Quand nous étions enfants, nous jouions sur la plage pendant des heures.
    \item Ne penses-tu pas que tu devrais changer de coiffure?
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a translation exercise for a student learning French. It should have a subsection for answers. It should be an exercise on using vous and est-ce que.
response:
Traduire les phrases suivantes en utilisant vous et la forme est-ce que si nécessaire.
\begin{enumerate}
    \item You must cook tonight.
    \item She must not work today.
    \item At what time is he supposed to arrive?
    \item How much do I owe you?
    \item Why must he sell his car?
    \item She owes an excuse to Carole.
    \item Are we supposed to know these verbs?
    \item He owes two thousand dollars to the bank.
    \item You should call Vincent.
    \item You should not invite Pierre.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
    \item Vous devez faire la cuisine ce soir.
    \item Elle ne doit pas travailler aujourd'hui.
    \item À quelle heure est-ce qu'il doit arriver?
    \item Combien est-ce que je vous dois?
    \item Pourquoi est-ce qu'il doit vendre sa voiture?
    \item Elle doit une excuse à Carole.
    \item Est-ce que nous devons connaître ces verbes?
    \item Il doit deux mille dollars à la banque.
    \item Vous devriez appeler Vincent.
    \item Vous ne devriez pas inviter Pierre.
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a comparison exercise for a 4th grade student learning social studies. It should be an exercise on urban and rural living.
response: Compare life in a city and life in a village.

instruction: Give me a comparison exercise for a 1st grade student learning history. It should be an exercise on comparing coal and electric irons.
response: Compare a coal iron and an electric iron. Write one way they are different. Write one way they are similar.

instruction: Give me a comparison exercise for a 1st grade student learning mathematics. It should be an exercise involving circling. It should be an exercise involving crossing out. It should have multiple steps.
response:
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Circle the greatest number: 19, 15, 12, 17, 9

\item Cross out the smallest number: 19, 15, 12, 17, 9
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a comparison exercise for a 6th grade student learning history. It should be an exercise on comparing Tudor towns with modern towns or cities.
response: What are the main differences between a Tudor town and the town or city you live in today? Are there any similarities?

instruction: Give me a comparison exercise for a 6th grade student learning history. It should be an exercise on modern and Tudor times football differences and similarities.
response: In what ways is the modern game of football different from football played in Tudor times? Are there any similarities?

instruction: Give me a comparison exercise for a 5th grade student learning history. It should be an exercise on comparing homes of different eras.
response: Compare the home of an ordinary Anglo-Saxon to the home you live in today. What are the main similarities and differences?

instruction: Give me a comparison exercise for a 5th grade student learning history. It should be an exercise on comparing Mayan cities to modern towns or cities.
response: Compare a Mayan city to the town or city you live in today. What are the main similarities and differences?

instruction: Give me a comparison exercise for a 2nd grade student learning history. It should be an exercise on comparing historical flights.
response: Compare the first hot air balloon flight with the first airplane flight. Write about how the flights were different and how they were similar.

instruction: Give me a comparison exercise for a 2nd grade student learning history. It should be an exercise on comparing old and modern toys and games.
response: Compare old and modern toys and games.

instruction: Give me a comparison exercise for a 3rd grade student learning mathematics. It should be an exercise involving identification. It should have multiple steps.
response:
Ring the greatest fraction:

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item \( \frac{1}{12} \), \( \frac{1}{7} \), \( \frac{1}{10} \)
\item \( \frac{1}{11} \), \( \frac{1}{8} \), \( \frac{1}{9} \)
\item \( \frac{6}{7} \), \( \frac{6}{10} \), \( \frac{6}{9} \)
\item \( \frac{7}{8} \), \( \frac{7}{12} \), \( \frac{7}{10} \)
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a combination of a comparison exercise and a fill in the blank exercise for a 3rd grade student learning mathematics. It should be an exercise on distance.
response:
Choose three places that are more than 1 km from your school, and three places that are less than 1 km from your school. Complete the table below.

\begin{table}[h]
\centering
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline
\textbf{Place} & \textbf{Distance from School (km)} \\
\hline
\text{Place 1 (more than 1 km)} & \_\_\_ \\
\hline
\text{Place 2 (more than 1 km)} & \_\_\_ \\
\hline
\text{Place 3 (more than 1 km)} & \_\_\_ \\
\hline
\text{Place 1 (less than 1 km)} & \_\_\_ \\
\hline
\text{Place 2 (less than 1 km)} & \_\_\_ \\
\hline
\text{Place 3 (less than 1 km)} & \_\_\_ \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{table}

instruction: Give me a creative exercise for a 3rd grade student learning computer science. It should be an exercise on digital stories and slideshows.
response:
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Think of a digital story you would like to write, then start a new slide show.  
\item Make a title slide for your digital story.  
\item Make the first slide of your digital story. 
Save your slide show.
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a creative exercise for a 6th grade student learning computer science. It should be an exercise on tactile representation.
response: Make a tactile representation titled 'Robots versus humans.' Use different textures or materials to represent the strengths of robots and humans. For example, use smooth materials for robots and rough ones for humans.

instruction: Give me a creative exercise for a 6th grade student learning history. It should be an activity on designing a poster for a Baghdad merchant.
response: Imagine you are a Baghdad merchant. Design a poster to advertise the goods you have for sale and to show that the goods have come from all over the world.

instruction: Give me a creative exercise for a 5th grade student learning social studies. It should be an activity on designing with Islamic elements.
response: Design a building or a garden that has Islamic elements.

instruction: Give me a creative exercise for a 2nd grade student learning computer science. It should be an activity on creating a poster.
response: Think of a poster you would like to create. Describe what you would add to it besides text, such as images or decorations.

instruction: Give me a creative exercise for a 3rd grade student learning social studies. It should be an activity on different types of transport in local area.
response: Draw and write about the different types of transport you can see in your local area.

instruction: Give me a creative exercise for a 1st grade student learning geography. It should be an exercise on building a model.
response: Use scrap materials to build a model of a house on stilts. What could you use to make the water around the house?

instruction: Give me a creative exercise for a 1st grade student learning history. It should be an activity on drawing a family tree.
response: Draw your family tree. How many boxes do you need for the people in each generation? Label each person with their name.

instruction: Give me a creative exercise for a 1st grade student learning social studies. It should be an activity on natural and built environments.
response: Draw and label two natural physical features and two parts of the built environment in your country.

instruction: Give me a creative exercise for a 1st grade student learning mathematics. It should be an exercise on picture creation.
response: Create your own set of pictures with topics: "In the morning," "In the afternoon," "After school," and "At night."

instruction: Give me a creative exercise for a 6th grade student learning social studies. It should be an activity on designing a sustainable city.
response: Work in a group to design a sustainable city.

instruction: Give me a combination of a group activity and a creative exercise for a 3rd grade student learning history. It should be an exercise on Iron Age settlements. It should be an activity involving poster design.
response: Work in a group. Find out about Iron Age settlements in your country. Create a large poster to show the information.

instruction: Give me a combination of a creative exercise and a writing exercise for a 3rd grade student learning social studies. It should be an activity on imagining future museum objects.
response: Draw an object from today that you think would be in a museum in the future. Write about what the object would tell people about life today.

instruction: Give me a combination of a drawing exercise and a creative exercise for a 1st grade student learning computer science. It should be an exercise that relates to the world.
response: Draw a picture of one thing you can do with a computer outside school. For example, make a picture of a car. Give your picture to your teacher.

instruction: Give me a combination of a creative exercise and a writing exercise for a 1st grade student learning English. It should have multiple steps. It should be an exercise on character description.
response:
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Draw a picture of a character from a story you have read.

\item Write a list of words to describe the character.

\item Use your words to write three sentences about the character.
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a combination of a drawing exercise and a creative exercise for a 1st grade student learning social studies. It should be an exercise on plan view.
response: Draw and label a plan view of part of your classroom.

instruction: Give me a combination of a creative exercise and a drawing exercise for a 1st grade student learning social studies. It should be an exercise on identifying needs and wants at home.
Give me a combination of an activity and a creative exercise for a 4th grade student learning science. It should be an exercise on electrical safety. It should be an exercise involving a poster.
response: Design a simple poster to display in your school about electrical safety.

instruction: Give me a combination of a creative exercise, a writing exercise, and a drawing exercise for a 2nd grade student learning computer science. It should have a subsection for materials. It should be an exercise on creating an advert for a nature reserve.
Give me a combination of a creative exercise and a writing exercise for a 2nd grade student learning social studies. It should be an exercise on food. It should be an activity on national dishes.
response: Draw and write about the national dish from your country and one other.

instruction: Give me a creative exercise for a 1st grade student learning mathematics. It should be an exercise related to counting.
response: Design a number sequence or pattern using 4, 7, and 8 objects.

instruction: Give me a creative exercise for a 4th grade student learning social studies. It should be an activity on uses of land.
response: Draw and write about four different uses of land in your country.

instruction: Give me a combination of a creative exercise and a group activity for a 3rd grade student learning history. It should be an activity on ancient civilization clothing.
response: Work in a group to create a poster of the clothes a family in an ancient civilisation might wear.

instruction: Give me a combination of a drawing exercise and a creative exercise for a 2nd grade student learning social studies. It should be an exercise on household budgets. It should be an activity on saving for household items.
response: Draw three things a household might have to save up for.

instruction: Give me a discussion exercise for a 4th grade student learning social studies. It should be an exercise on school life. It should be an activity on improving school life.
response: Work with a friend to discuss how happy you are with life in school. Suggest one idea that you think will improve school life.

instruction: Give me a discussion exercise for a 1st grade student learning history. It should be an exercise on Columbus giving gifts.
response: Why do you think Columbus gave the king and queen a pineapple and a turkey? Explain your ideas to a friend.

instruction: Give me a discussion exercise for a 1st grade student learning social studies. It should be an exercise on changes over generations.
response: Discuss two things that have changed since your parents were children.

instruction: Give me a discussion exercise for a 5th grade student learning history. It should be an exercise on Roman soldiers' retirement.
response: What might a Roman soldier do when he retired?

instruction: Give me a discussion exercise for a 5th grade student learning science. It should be an exercise on mirrors. It should be an exercise on examples.
response: Talk about examples of mirrors.

instruction: Give me a discussion exercise for a 5th grade student learning science. It should be an exercise on the roundness of Earth. It should be an exercise on scientific proof.
response: Discuss how scientists prove that the Earth is round.

instruction: Give me a discussion exercise for a 2nd grade student learning history. It should be an exercise on comparing historical and modern cars.
response: How is Karl Benz's car different from the cars people drive today? Tell a friend your ideas.

instruction: Give me a discussion exercise for a 2nd grade student learning history. It should be an exercise on interpreting quotes.
response: Neil Armstrong said: ‘That's one small step for a man, one giant leap for mankind.' Explain to a friend what you think this means.

instruction: Give me a discussion exercise for a 3rd grade student learning history. It should be an exercise on identifying turning points in history.
response: Good historians identify ‘turning points' in history when things changed completely. Can you say why farming is a turning point?

instruction: Give me a discussion exercise for a 6th grade student learning social studies. It should be an exercise on the WHO. It should be an exercise involving group discussion.
response:
The constitution of the World Health Organisation (WHO) states that ‘the enjoyment of the highest attainable standard of health is one of the fundamental rights of every human being'.

Work in a group to discuss this statement and what it means for governments and individuals.

instruction: Give me a discussion exercise for a 6th grade student learning social studies. It should be an exercise on climate change.

response:
\begin{enumerate}

\item Explore each object one at a time until you have an answer to your question.

\item Look at your results and discuss them with your group.

Give me a combination of an activity and an investigation exercise for a 3rd grade student learning science. It should be an exercise on how objects change shape.
response:
\begin{enumerate}
  \item Plan your exploration of how objects change shape.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Choose at least two objects to explore.
    \item Decide which type of force to apply for each object – a pull or a push, or both.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Make a small drawing of each object to show its shape before you try to change its shape.
  \item Draw a table to record your predictions and the results of your exploration.

    \item Prediction
    \item Drawing of object after force is applied
    \item Was the prediction correct?
  \end{itemize}
  \item Try to change the shape of each object and record the result in a small drawing.
  \item When all objects have been tested, compare your predictions with your results and fill in the last column with ‘yes’ or ‘no’ for each one.
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a combination of an investigation exercise, a question exercise, and a group activity for a 5th grade student learning science. It should have a subsection for materials. It should be an exercise on growing and shrinking shadows. It should be an exercise involving a table. It should be an exercise involving data collection. The exercise should contain some kind of a graphic component (illustration, diagram, table, etc).
response:
In groups, carry out an investigation to explore if your prediction is true.
\begin{enumerate}
\item Using a torch as your light source, place it 2 meters away from a screen or wall and fix it in place so it does not move.
\item Choose an opaque object that is easy to move. You will need to measure this object, so choose something that has a simple shape, such as a building block.
\item Place the object 10 centimetres in front of the light source and measure the length of its shadow.
\item Now measure the size of the shadow from the same object at 20 centimetres, 30 centimetres, 40 centimetres, and 50 centimetres away from the light source.
\item In your Investigation Notebook, record your results in a table.
\item What do you notice about your results? Can you see a pattern?
\item Was your prediction at the start of the investigation correct?
\item Which variables were kept the same in the investigation to make sure it was a fair test?
\item Why does the shadow of an object get bigger as the object is moved closer to the light?
\item How can you collect reliable data?
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] The diagram shows how light travels from a light source to create shadows. It illustrates a near object casting a larger shadow and a distant object casting a smaller shadow, with arrows indicating the path of light. [STPDGM]

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
\item A torch
\item An opaque object
\item Measuring tape
\end{itemize}

instruction: Give me a combination of an activity and an investigation exercise for a 5th grade student learning science. It should be an exercise on filtering. The exercise should contain some kind of a graphic component (illustration, diagram, table, etc).
response:
\begin{enumerate}
  \item Choose a solution to work with. Plan how to separate the solid from the solution:
  \begin{itemize}
    \item in a slow way
    \item in a faster way
  \end{itemize}
  \item Write down what your group will do. Plan your investigation in detail.
  \item When your plan is complete, show it to your teacher.
  \item Make a prediction of which method will be faster, and write it down.
  \item Collect the things you need to make a solution and make enough for repeating your methods three times each.
  \item Carry out your plan for the fast method and observe what happens. Record your observations in drawings and text as you go along.
  \item When you have a clear result, repeat the method another two times in exactly the same way. Observe and record what happens each time.
  \item Now carry out the slow method. It might be possible to do all three at the same time. Observe and record what happens each time, as you did for the first method.
  \item Look at your results:
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Discuss your results with your group.
    \item Write down your group’s conclusion and share it with the class.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Compare your methods with the methods used by other groups:
  \begin{enumerate}
    \item Which one was the fastest?
    \item Why? Try to explain your answer.
  \end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}
[STRDGM] The image shows two setups for evaporation: one with a shallow dish in sunlight and another with a heated crucible. The first setup has a dish with liquid and is exposed to sunlight, while the second has a heated container with liquid boiling. Arrows indicate the direction of vapor rising from both setups. [STPDGM]

instruction: Give me a combination of an activity, a group discussion, and an investigation exercise for a 4th grade student learning science. It should have a subsection for materials. It should be an exercise on pitch. It should be an exercise involving a table.

Give me a combination of a group activity, a discussion exercise, and an investigation exercise for a 4th grade student learning science. It should be an exercise on sound. It should be an activity on sound transmission.
response:
\begin{enumerate}
  \item Discuss with your group which materials you think can reduce or prevent sound travelling from its source (its transmission).
  \item Plan an investigation of how sound transmission can be prevented or reduced.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Make it a fair test, using at least three materials and a sound source.
    \item Predict what you think the results will show.
    \item Write down your prediction.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Decide how you will observe the reduction or prevention of the sound. What will you measure, and how?
  \item Decide how you will record your observations and prepare for the recording.
  \item Compare the effects of the three different materials on the transmission of the sound.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Carry out the test in a fair way so that you will be able to compare the effects.
    \item Record your measurements each time.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Compare your results.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Use them to make a conclusion about the three materials.
    \item Compare your results with your prediction.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Share your group’s results with the class and compare them with those from other groups.
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me an activity for a 2nd grade student learning science. It should be an exercise on materials. It should be an exercise involving heating and cooling.
response:
\begin{enumerate}
  \item Choose two of the following materials for your exploration: wax, chocolate, butter, ice.
  \item Talk with your group about how you will explore the way these materials change:
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item when they are heated
    \item when they are cooled.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Plan to make your exploration fair.
  \item Decide what equipment you need and collect it.
  \item Choose how you will record what you find out.
  \item Make predictions about both materials, and write down your predictions. Say:
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item how they will change when heated
    \item how they will change when cooled.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Heat the first material.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Observe it closely. What can you smell, hear and see?
    \item Record any changes.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item When there are no more changes, let the material cool.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Observe it closely.
    \item Record any changes.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Use the second material. Do the heating and cooling as you did with the first one.
  \item Record what you found out.
  \item Compare your results with what you predicted might happen. Were your predictions right?
  \item Compare the way the two materials were changed by heating and cooling.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item What was the same?
    \item What was different?
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Share with the class what you found out.
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a multiple choice exercise for a student learning Spanish. It should have a subsection for answers. It should be an exercise on informal conversation.
response:
Choose the right answer.  
\begin{enumerate}
    \item “No me gustan las aceitunas” “A mí tampoco.” What does “A mí tampoco” mean here?
    \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
        \item Me neither / Nor me.
        \item I don't.
        \item Me too.
    \end{enumerate}

    \item Which one of these is said in an informal conversation?
    \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
        \item Yo no amo más las fresas.
        \item Yo amo no las fresas.
        \item Yo no amo las fresas.
    \end{enumerate}

    \item “¿Quién rompió ese jarrón?!” “¡Yo no!” What does “Yo no!” mean here?
    \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
        \item Me!
        \item Not me!
        \item Him!
    \end{enumerate}

    \item “Mamá, ¿puedo salir esta tarde?” “¡De ninguna manera!” What does “¡De ninguna manera!” mean here?
    \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
        \item No way!
        \item Don't!
        \item No question.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Me neither.
\item Yo no amo las fresas.
\item Not me!
\item No way!
\end{enumerate}

    \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_

\item Finish these sentences about yourself.\\
My name is \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_.\\
I live with my \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_.
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a writing exercise for a 6th grade student learning English. It should be an exercise on expressing opinions.
response:

instruction: Give me a writing exercise for a 6th grade student learning social studies. It should be an exercise on speech writing. It should be an exercise on deforestation.
response: Prepare a speech for a public meeting which is opposing a new quarry that will remove some forest. Your speech should explain the importance of the forest and the problems associated with deforestation.

response: Write a brief report describing the climate and weather features of the Arabian Gulf countries. Explain their effects on human activity.

response: Write a description of the bicycle. Write about what colour it is. Write about the parts it has.

instruction: Give me a writing exercise for a 2nd grade student learning English. It should be an exercise on writing months of the year.
response: Write the months of the year in order. Remember to use a capital letter!

instruction: Give me a writing exercise for a student learning Dutch. It should be an exercise involving an example. It should be an exercise on changing questions into orders.
response:
Can you change the following questions into orders? For example:\\
Kun je de deur dicht doen? --> Doe de deur dicht.\\
\begin{enumerate}
\item Kun je straks de boodschappen doen?
\item Kun je me vanavond bellen?
\item Kun je deze les voor morgen leren?

\item Wil je niet zo hard schreeuwen?
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a writing exercise for a student learning Dutch. It should be an exercise on comparing public figures using adjectives.
response:

Use adjectives you already know and some from this list in your description:

\begin{enumerate}
\item conservatief conservative
\item progressief progressive
\item tolerant tolerant
\item agressief aggressive
\item dik fat
\item slank slim
\item aantrekkelijk attractive
\item intelligent intelligent
\item dom stupid
\item stijf stiff
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a writing exercise for a student learning Spanish. It should be an exercise on using verbs in the imperfect tense.

response:

\item More haste less speed.
\item Two heads are better than one.
\item While the cat's away the mice will play.
\item Birds of a feather flock together.
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a writing exercise for a 6th grade student learning English. It should be an exercise on "ough" words.
response: Write eight different "ough" words. An "ough" word is a word that contains "ough", like for example "dough"

I have to write an adventure story this weekend. I have been trying to think about what to write. I haven't come up with any ideas!

instruction: Give me a writing exercise for a 4th grade student learning English. It should be an exercise on rewriting notes into sentences.

Give me a writing exercise for a 4th grade student learning English. It should have multiple steps. The exercise should contain some kind of a graphic component (illustration, diagram, table, etc). It should be an exercise on planning a story.
response:
Plan and write a story in which the main character has one of the following problems:
\begin{itemize}
\item Your main character knows that his/her friend has broken a window in a neighbour's house.
\item Your main character knows that his/her friend has borrowed a bicycle without permission and damaged it.
\end{itemize}
What should your main character do?

\begin{enumerate}
\item Which story are you planning? Tick one. the broken window $\Box$  the borrowed bicycle $\Box$
\item What is your main character's name? \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item What is the friend's name? \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item Where does your story take place? \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item Describe what the main character sees and how it happens.\\
   \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\\
   \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item Think of two things your main character could do about what he/she has seen. He/she could:
   \begin{enumerate}
   \item \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
   \item \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
   \end{enumerate}
\item What does your main character decide to do?\\
   \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\\
   \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] Two illustrations: one showing a broken window with a character looking at it, and another showing a character with a damaged bicycle. [STPDGM]

instruction: Give me a writing exercise for a 4th grade student learning social studies. It should be an exercise on personal goals. It should be an exercise involving listing.
response: Make a list showing goals you have in school now, goals outside school and goals for the future.

instruction: Give me a writing exercise for a 4th grade student learning social studies. It should be an exercise on interpersonal skills.
response: Make a list of situations in which you use different interpersonal skills and explain how you communicate.

instruction: Give me a writing exercise for a 4th grade student learning social studies. It should be an exercise on local government responsibilities.
response: Make a list of things you think the local government does to keep your area looking its best. Suggest any other things that you think they should do.

response:

\begin{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a writing exercise for a 2nd grade student learning English. It should be an exercise on creating contractions.
response:
Rewrite each sentence and change the underlined words as another word to create contractions:
\begin{enumerate}
\item I am feeling much \underline{better}. \_\_\_\_\_\_
\item We are eating \underline{fruit}. \_\_\_\_\_\_
\item They are \underline{spilling} water. \_\_\_\_\_\_

instruction: Give me a writing exercise for a 2nd grade student learning English. It should be an exercise on word generation.
response: How many words with a "wa" can you write? Come up with at least four!

instruction: Give me a writing exercise for a student learning German. It should be an exercise on word forms. It should be a with Answer.
response:
Provide the correct form of the words inside the parenthesis in the following sentences.

\begin{enumerate}
\item Die (alt) Frau ist immer noch (stark). \\
   (The old woman is still strong.)
\item Anne schenkte (ihr) (schön) Mutter a (schön) Schmuck. \\
   (Anne gave her beautiful mother a beautiful dress.)
\item Wir gingen zur Farm (der) (freundlich) (Mann). \\
   (We went to the friendly man's garden.)
\item (der) (hell) Lichter blenden meine Augen. \\
   (The bright lights are blinding my eyes.)
\item Ich kann (mein) Socken nicht finden. \\
   (I can't find my socks.)
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item alte, stark
\item ihrer, schönen, schönes
\item des, freundlichen, Mannes
\item die, hellen
\item meine
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a writing exercise for a student learning Dutch. It should be an exercise on forming questions and answers. It should be an exercise involving one or more examples. It should be an exercise involving an entertaining tone.
response: Ask several questions using the interrogative pronouns hoe (how), wie (who), wat (what), waar (where), wanneer (when). And while you are at it, how about forming an answer to them as well? Example: (1) "Hoe werkt dit keukenapparaat? Dat kun je beter aan mijn vader vragen." (2) "Hoe laat vertrekt de trein naar Amsterdam? De volgende trein vertrekt om kwart over vier." Write down ten of these sets and call yourself an advanced speaker of Dutch!

instruction: Give me a writing exercise for a student learning Dutch. It should have a subsection for hints. It should be an exercise on writing phrases.
response:
Write down ten simple sentences with: an article, a noun, an adjective, and a preposition. Keep it simple, no verbs yet!
For instance: A nice book under the sofa – wow, two articles, two nouns, one adjective, and one preposition!

\subsection*{Hints}
Feel free to look up words in the dictionary that don’t come to mind.

instruction: Give me a writing exercise for a student learning Dutch. It should be an exercise on using verbs to make sentences.
response:
Look at this list of activities:
\begin{enumerate}
\item mijn haar wassen - to wash my hair
\item in de tuin werken - to work in the garden
\item eten koken - to cook dinner (literally: to cook food)
\item mijn zoon met zijn huiswerk helpen - to help my son with his homework
\item naar het feest van Maria gaan - to go to Maria's party
\item een cadeau voor Maria kopen - to buy a present for Maria
\item foto's in het museum maken - to take pictures in the museum
\end{enumerate}

Use the verbs gaan, mogen, moeten, willen and kunnen to make sentences about these listed activities.\\
Which verb you use depends on what seems appropriate to you, whether you can, want, are allowed or have to do these activities.

instruction: Give me a writing exercise for a student learning Dutch. It should have a subsection for answers. It should be an exercise involving an example. It should be an exercise on asking yes/no questions.
response:
Practice checking information you have about people on a list by asking yes/no questions. Formulate your questions according to patterns you know. For example: Bent u meneer Plantinga? Woon jij in Heerenveen? Is jouw adres Turfstraat

\begin{enumerate}
\item Meneer Plantinga\\
woonplaats: Harderwijk\\
beroep: politieagent\\
adres: Pijlslaan 15\\
postcode: 2586 AL\\
telefoonnummer: 4326781
\item Kaatje Lijbers\\
woonplaats: Heerenveen\\
beroep: verpleegster\\
adres: Seringenlaan 18\\
postcode: 1864 KN\\
telefoonnummer: 567392
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Bent u meneer Plantinga?\\
Ben u politieagent?\\
Woon u in Harderwijk?\\
Is uw adres Pijlslaan 15?\\
Is uw postcode 2586 AL?\\
Is uw telefoonnummer 4326781?
\item Bent u Kaatje Lijbers?\\
Ben u verpleegster?\\
Woon u in Heerenveen?\\
Is uw adres Seringenlaan 18?\\
Is uw postcode 1864 KN?\\
Is uw telefoonnummer 567392?
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a writing exercise for a student learning Dutch. It should be an exercise involving an example. It should be an exercise on likes and activities.
response:
Make a list of your own and your relatives' or friends' likes as far as activities are concerned.  
For example:  
Ik hou van fietsen.  
Mijn vriend John houdt van skateboarden (skateboarding).

instruction: Give me a writing exercise for a student learning Dutch. It should be an exercise on numbers and measures. It should be an exercise on creating a shopping list.
response:
You're going to the supermarket.  
Make up a boodschappenlijstje of as many things as you would normally buy in real life.  
You might want to try and use a dictionary.  
Once you have your own boodschappenlijstje use it to say what you need or want to buy, using the following structures:  
Ik heb ... nodig (I need ...)  
Ik wil ... (I want ...)  

Try and be as specific as possible about how much you need.  
Here are some weights and measures:  
een gram (gram)  
een kilo (a kilo)  
een liter (a litre)  
een ons (an ounce, 100 grams)  
een pond (a pound, 500 grams)

instruction: Give me a writing exercise for a student learning Spanish. It should be an exercise on writing country names. It should be a with Answer.
Give me a writing exercise for a student learning French. It should be an exercise on rewriting. It should be a with Answer.
response:
Réécrire les phrases suivantes en traduisant les expressions entre parenthèses.

\begin{enumerate}
    \item Elle passe ses après-midi (cooking).
    \item Ils passent leurs nuits (dancing).
    \item Ils sont accoudés au comptoir (talking).
    \item Elle est assise (peeling vegetables).
    \item Il a gaspillé sa vie (working for them).
    \item Tu as perdu ton temps (looking for another job).
    \item Je suis allongée sur la plage (reading).
    \item Elle est debout dans le jardin (picking some flowers).
    \item Il passe son temps (dreaming).
    \item Ils passent leurs journées (shopping).
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item à faire la cuisine
\item à danser
\item à parler
\item à éplucher des légumes
\item à travailler pour eux
\item à chercher un autre travail
\item à lire
\item à cueillir des fleurs
\item à rêver
\item à faire les courses
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a long answer exercise for a 4th grade student learning social studies. It should be an exercise on responsibilities. It should be an exercise on decision-making.

instruction: Give me a long answer exercise for a 1st grade student learning history. It should be an exercise on personal development.

instruction: Give me a long answer exercise for a 5th grade student learning history. It should be an exercise on daily life comparison.

Give me a grammar exercise for a student learning German. It should be an exercise on tense modification. It should be a with Answer.
response:
Restate the following present tense sentences in the present perfect tense.

\begin{enumerate}
\item Musst du zu Hause bleiben? (Do you have to stay at home?) \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item Mein Vetter kann Klavier spielen. (My cousin can play the piano.) \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item Darf er mit deiner Frau tanzen? (May he dance with your wife?) \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item Der Lehrer soll lauter sprechen. (The teacher should talk louder.) \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item Wir wollen Brot mit Käse essen. (We want to eat bread with cheese.) \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item Ich muss viel arbeiten. (I have to work a lot.) \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item Die Jungen können Tennis spielen. (The boys can play tennis.) \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item Dürft ihr mit der Katze spielen? (Are you allowed to play with the cat?) \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item Die Männer sollen weniger Bier trinken. (The men should drink less beer.) \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item Will sie Karl kennen lernen? (Does she want to meet Karl?) \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Hast du zu Hause bleiben müssen? \\
(Did you have to stay at home?)
\item Mein Vetter hat Klavier spielen können. \\
(My cousin could play the piano.)
\item Hat er mit deiner Frau tanzen dürfen? \\
(Was he allowed to dance with your wife?)
\item Der Lehrer hat lauter sprechen sollen. \\
(The teacher should have talked louder.)
\item Wir haben Brot mit Käse essen wollen. \\
(We have wanted to eat bread with cheese.)
\item Ich habe viel arbeiten müssen. \\
(I have had to work a lot.)
\item Die Jungen haben Tennis spielen können. \\
(The boys could play tennis.)
\item Habt ihr mit der Katze spielen dürfen? \\
(Were you allowed to play with the cat?)
\item Die Männer haben weniger Bier trinken sollen. \\
(The men should have drunk less beer.)
\item Hat sie Karl kennen lernen wollen? \\
(Did she want to meet Karl?)
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a grammar exercise for a student learning German. It should be an exercise on rephrasing verbs with pronouns. It should be a with Answer.
response:
Restate each verb with the pronouns ich and er. For example:\\
kommen: ich komme - er kommt

\begin{enumerate}
\item fahren \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item mitkommen \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item bekommen \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item lesen \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item verstehen \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item sprechen \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item beibringen \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item fallen \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item aufhören \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item erwarten \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item fahren \\
   ich fahre \\
   er fährt
\item mitkommen \\
   ich komme mit \\
   er kommt mit
\item bekommen \\
   ich bekomme \\
   er bekommt
\item lesen \\
   ich lese  \\
   er liest
\item verstehen \\
   ich verstehe  \\
   er versteht
\item sprechen \\
   ich spreche  \\
   er spricht
\item beibringen \\
   ich bringe bei  \\
   er bringt bei
\item fallen \\
   ich falle  \\
   er fällt
\item aufhören \\
   ich höre auf \\
   er hört auf
\item erwarten \\
   ich erwarte \\
   er erwartet
\end{enumerate}

response:
Choose the correct adjective for the following sentences.

    \item Elena y Camila son muy:
        \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
            \item trabajador
            \item trabajadoras
        \end{enumerate}

    \item Me he comprado unos zapatos:
        \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
            \item negres
            \item negros
        \end{enumerate}

    \item Marco y Andrés son:
        \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
            \item altos y morenos
            \item altes y morenos
        \end{enumerate}

    \item Él es un hombre:
        \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
            \item leal
            \item leal
        \end{enumerate}

    \item Ella es muy:
        \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
            \item tímida
            \item tímidas
        \end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Trabajadoras
\item Negros
\item Altos y morenos
\item Leal
\item Tímida
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a grammar exercise for a student learning Spanish. It should be an exercise on rewriting sentences in singular. It should be a with Answer.
Give me a grammar exercise for a student learning Spanish. It should be an exercise on rearranging words. It should be a with Answer.
Give me a grammar exercise for a student learning Spanish. It should be an exercise on identifying nouns. It should be a with Answer.
response:
Identify which words in the following Spanish conversation are nouns.  

Marta: Bienvenido a mi oficina. (Welcome to my office.)
Julio: Gracias. (Thank you.)  
Marta: Vamos a la sala de conferencias. Ahí tengo un proyector y una televisión. Podemos ver el documental. La secretaria preparó café. Todavía está caliente. (Let's go to the conference room. I have a projector and television there. We can watch the documentary. The secretary made coffee. It's still warm.)
Julio: ¿Dónde está el baño? (Where is the bathroom?)  
Marta: Uno está aquí y el otro está en el primer piso. (One is here, the other is on the first floor.)  

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
    \item Oficina
    \item Sala de conferencias
    \item Proyector
    \item Televisión
    \item Documental
    \item Café
    \item Baño
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a grammar exercise for a student learning French. It should be an exercise on the passé composé. It should be a with Answer.
response:
Mettre les phrases suivantes au passé composé.
\begin{enumerate}
    \item Ils voyagent souvent en Asie.
    \item On mange bien chez eux.
    \item Elle dépense beaucoup.
    \item Il lit rarement des romans policiers.
    \item Nous ne travaillons pas assez.
    \item Je parle trop.
    \item Elle écrit très peu.
    \item Tu vas souvent au théâtre.
    \item Il s'exprime toujours très mal.
    \item Nous aimons bien la maison.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
    \item Ils ont souvent voyagé en Asie.
    \item On a bien mangé chez eux.
    \item Elle a beaucoup dépensé.
    \item Il a rarement lu des romans policiers.
    \item Nous n'avons pas assez travaillé.
    \item J'ai trop parlé.
    \item Elle a très peu écrit.
    \item Tu es souvent allé(e) au théâtre.
    \item Il s'est toujours très mal exprimé.
    \item Nous avons bien aimé la maison.
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a grammar exercise for a student learning French. It should be an exercise on transformation. It should be an exercise on using active voice. It should be a with Answer.
response:
Mettre les phrases suivantes à la voix active. Attention aux temps de verbe!
\begin{enumerate}
    \item Le gâteau a été fait par le chef.
    \item L'objet a été conçu par l'artisan.
    \item Le château a été érigé par le roi.
    \item Le document sera signé par l'ambassadeur.
    \item Le tableau a été vendu par le propriétaire.
    \item Le fauteuil est griffé par le chat.
    \item L'amende a été payée par le malfaiteur.
    \item Le vase a été volé par l'antiquaire.
    \item Le livre sera écrit par un journaliste.
    \item Les élèves sont punis par le professeur.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Le chef a fait le gâteau.
\item L'artisan a conçu l'objet.
\item Le roi a érigé le château.
\item L'ambassadeur signera le document.
\item Le propriétaire a vendu le tableau.
\item Le chat griffé le fauteuil.
\item Le malfaiteur a payé l'amende.
\item L'antiquaire a volé le vase.
\item Un journaliste écrira le livre.
\item Le professeur punit les élèves.
\end{enumerate}
