Give me a grammar exercise for a student learning German. It should be an exercise on using accusative pronouns. It should be a with Answer.
response:
Practice using the accusative by changing the underlined noun direct object in each sentence to the appropriate pronoun direct object.\\
For example, when presented with the sentence "Sie haben eine Zeitung," you would change it to "Sie haben sie."

\begin{enumerate}
\item Sie haben die Bluse. (They have the blouse.)
\item Sie haben eine Jacke. (They have a jacket.)
\item Haben Sie die Zeitung? (Do you have the newspaper?)
\item Sehen Sie das Bett? (Do you see the bed?)
\item Hans und Andreas sehen den Lehrer nicht.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Sie haben sie.
\item Sie haben sie.
\item Haben Sie sie?
\item Sehen Sie es?
\item Hans und Andreas sehen ihn nicht.
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a grammar exercise for a student learning Dutch. It should have multiple steps. It should be an exercise involving an example. It should be an exercise on using "wel".
response:
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item You can use wel to emphasize a certain point and to indicate that something is the case, whereas something else wasn't. In English there is no special word to use here, but you change the tone of your voice. The example will make this clear:
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Ik ben geen echte Ram. / I am not a real Aries.
\item Ik ben wel een echte Ram. / I am a real Aries.
\end{enumerate}
In fact, (b) could also simply have answered:\\
Ik wel. (I am.)\\

Now reply to the following statements, using wel. (Answer with ik.). Answer in full sentences, even though Ik wel would suffice in most cases.

\begin{enumerate}
\item Ik ben niet filosofisch.
\item Zij houdt niet van humeurige mensen.
\item Hij is geen geboren leider.
\item Zij gaan niet op vakantie in de zomer.
\item Jij hebt geen auto.
\item Ik ben vaak niet veeleisend genoeg (enough).
\end{enumerate}

\item Wel is often used with its opposite niet (or geen). Using wel and niet, make up a list of characteristics that you do or don't possess. Make some five pairs, following the examples:\\
Ik ben niet bazig maar wel koppig. / I am not bossy but I am headstrong.\\
Ik ben niet kleinzielig maar wel veeleisend. / I am not small-minded but I am demanding.\\
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a grammar exercise for a student learning Dutch. It should be an exercise on object pronouns. It should be a with Answer.
response:
Complete the sentences and substitute the words in brackets by one of the object pronouns in the list:

\begin{enumerate}
\item mij - me
\item jou - you
\item u - you
\item hem - him
\item haar - her
\item ons - us
\item jullie - you
\item u - you
\item hen/hun/ze - them
\end{enumerate}

\begin{enumerate}
\item Herman werkt met ... (Tania).
\item Geef ... (ik) maar een stukje appeltaart.
\item Jaap helpt ... (Jan en Luuk).
\item Kees woont met ... (wij) samen (samen = together).
\item Is dit van ... (jij)?
\item Ik kus ... (mijn man).
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Herman werkt met haar.
\item Geef mij maar een stukje appeltaart.
\item Jaap helpt hen.
\item Kees woont met ons samen.
\item Is dit van jou?
\item Ik kus hem.
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a grammar exercise for a student learning Spanish. It should be an exercise on imperatives. It should be a with Answer.
response:
Write the imperative as shown in the example.  
Example: (Darme su pasaporte). Usted → Deme su pasaporte.  
\begin{enumerate}
    \item (Ayudar a las estudiantes). Tú →
    \item (Venderle su casa). Usted →
    \item (Salir por allá). Ustedes →
    \item (Escribir más rápido). Ustedes →
    \item (Estudiar menos horas). Tú →
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Ayuda a las estudiantes.
\item Véndale su casa.
\item Salgan por allá.
\item Escriban más rápido.
\item Estudia menos horas.
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a grammar exercise for a student learning French. It should be an exercise on distinction. It should be a with Answer.
response:
Faire la distinction entre les deux éléments en ajoutant -ci et -là aux noms qui suivent les adjectifs démonstratifs.

\begin{enumerate}
    \item Ma mère achète les biscuits dans (this) pâtisserie et les gâteaux dans (that) pâtisserie.
    \item Leur enfant joue avec (this) jouet mais il ne joue pas avec (that) jouet.
    \item Mes parents habitent loin d'ici. (This) cousin habite à San Francisco, (that) cousin est à New York.
    \item (This) maison appartient à Tante Marthe, (that) maison appartient à son fils.
    \item (This) neveu et (that) neveu sont nés le même jour.
    \item Mon mari aime (this) belle-sœur, mais il n'aime pas (that) belle-sœur.
    \item Son frère a écrit (this) roman, mais il n'a pas écrit (that) roman.
    \item Leurs enfants aiment (this) jeu mais ils n'aiment pas (that) jeu.
    \item (This) poupée et (that) poupée sont des cadeaux de Tante Agathe.
    \item (This) carte est un souvenir de voyage, (that) carte est un cadeau.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
    \item cette pâtisserie-ci / cette pâtisserie-là
    \item ce jouet-ci / ce jouet-là
    \item Ce cousin-ci / ce cousin-là
    \item Cette maison-ci / cette maison-là
    \item Ce neveu-ci / ce neveu-là
    \item cette belle-sœur-ci / cette belle-sœur-là
    \item ce roman-ci / ce roman-là
    \item ce jeu-ci / ce jeu-là
    \item Cette poupée-ci / cette poupée-là
    \item cette carte-ci / cette carte-là
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a grammar exercise for a student learning French. It should have a subsection for answers. It should be an exercise on imperative mood.
response:
Mettre à l'impératif les phrases suivantes:
\begin{enumerate}
    \item Prendre le train de neuf heures. (tu)
    \item Regarder le film à la télé ce soir. (vous)
    \item Dîner sur la terrasse. (nous)
    \item Acheter le journal. (tu)
    \item Boire à sa santé. (nous)
    \item Expliquer les conditions. (vous)
    \item Ne pas courir si vite. (tu)
    \item Épeler ton nom. (tu)
    \item Prêter votre dictionnaire à Marie. (vous)
    \item Ne pas inviter Denis. (tu)
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Prends le train de neuf heures!
\item Regardez le film à la télé ce soir!
\item Dînons sur la terrasse!
\item Achète le journal!
\item Buvons à sa santé!
\item Expliquez les conditions!
\item Ne cours pas si vite!
\item Épelle ton nom!
\item Prêtez votre dictionnaire à Marie!
\item N'invite pas Denis!
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a grammar exercise for a student learning French. It should have a subsection for answers. It should be an exercise on indicative and subjunctive moods.
response:
Mettre les verbes entre parenthèses au subjonctif ou à l'indicatif.
\begin{enumerate}
    \item Il dit que leur page d'accueil (\textit{être})          attrayante.
    \item Elle doute qu'il (\textit{faire})          chaud demain.
    \item Ils sont heureux que leurs enfants (\textit{pouvoir})          aller en Europe cet été.
    \item Je pense que Maud (\textit{avoir})          raison.
    \item Je veux que tu (\textit{faire})          la présentation jeudi.
    \item Tu ne crois pas qu'ils (\textit{avoir})          assez d'expérience.
    \item Vous savez qu'ils (\textit{être})          toujours en retard.
    \item Nous souhaitons que vous (\textit{obtenir})          ce poste.
    \item Ils exigent que vous (\textit{parler})          une langue étrangère.
    \item Vous savez que cet ordinateur (\textit{être})          obsolète.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
    \item est
    \item fasse
    \item puissent
    \item a
    \item fasses
    \item aient
    \item sont
    \item obteniez
    \item parliez
    \item est
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a grammar exercise for a student learning French. It should be an exercise on the futur antérieur. It should be a with Answer.
response:
Mettre les verbes entre parenthèses au futur antérieur.
\begin{enumerate}
    \item Elle (apprendre)          le français au Laos.
    \item Il (finir)          son roman avant la fin de l'année.
    \item Nous (visiter)          tous les sites historiques de la région.
    \item Les chercheurs (trouver)          un nouveau vaccin.
    \item On (découvrir)          un remède plus efficace.
    \item Je (répondre)          à toutes les questions.
    \item Elle (se reposer)          des semaines au bord du lac.
    \item Ils (compléter)          leur stage de formation.
    \item Il (mourir)          depuis longtemps.
    \item Je (voir)          l'essentiel.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
    \item aura appris
    \item aura fini
    \item aurons visité
    \item auront trouvé
    \item aura découvert
    \item J'aurai répondu
    \item se sera reposée
    \item auront complété
    \item sera mort
    \item J'aurai vu
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a grammar exercise for a student learning German. It should have a subsection for answers. It should be an exercise involving one or more examples. It should be an exercise on restating phrases in different tenses.

ich lerne:\\
ich habe gelernt - ich hatte gelernt - ich werde gelernt haben

\begin{enumerate}
\item er schlägt: \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ - \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ - \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item sie (pl.) bringen: \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ - \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ - \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item es passiert: \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ - \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ - \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item sie (sing.) ist: \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ - \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ - \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item du hast: \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ - \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ - \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item ihr esst: \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ - \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ - \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item Sie kommen: \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ - \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ - \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item wer reist: \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ - \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ - \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item wir setzen: \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ - \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ - \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item ich sehe: \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ - \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ - \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}

\begin{enumerate}
\item er hat geschlagen - er hatte geschlagen - er wird geschlagen haben
\item sie haben gebracht - sie hatten gebracht - sie werden gebracht haben
\item es ist passiert - es war passiert - es wird passiert sein
\item sie ist gewesen - sie war gewesen - sie wird gewesen sein
\item du hast gehabt - du hattest gehabt - du wirst gehabt haben
\item ihr habt gegessen - ihr hattet gegessen - ihr werdet gegessen haben
\item Sie sind gekommen - Sie waren gekommen - Sie werden gekommen sein
\item wer ist gereist - wer war gereist - wer wird gereist sein
\item wir haben gesetzt  -  wir hatten gesetzt - wir werden gesetzt haben
\item ich habe gesehen - ich hatte gesehen - ich werde gesehen haben
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a grammar exercise for a student learning German. It should be an exercise on the past perfect tense. It should be a with Answer.
response:
Restate the sentences below in the past perfect tense. Watch for verbs that use sein rather than haben as the auxiliary.

\begin{enumerate}
\item Hans und Maria laufen in den Garten. (Hans and Maria run into the garden.) \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item Ich bekomme einen Brief von Helga. (I receive a letter from Helga.) \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item Wer repariert den Wagen? (Who is repairing the car?) \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item Er fragt mich. (He asks me.) \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item Ich trinke ein Glas Wasser. (I am drinking a glass of water.) \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item Wir reisen nach Berlin. (We travel to Berlin.) \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item Liest du das Buch? (Are you reading the book?) \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item Er trägt einen Hut. (He wears a hat.) \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item Ich bleibe zu Hause. (I stay home.) \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Hans und Maria waren in den Garten gelaufen. (Hans and Maria had run in the garden.)
\item Ich hatte einen Brief von Helga bekommen. (I had received a letter from Helga.)
\item Wer hatte den Wagen repariert? (Who had repaired the car?)
\item Er hatte mich gefragt. (He had asked me.)
\item Ich hatte ein Glas Wasser getrunken. (I had drunk a glass of water.)
\item Wir waren nach Berlin gereist. (We had traveled to Berlin.)
\item Hattest du das Buch gelesen? (Had you read the book?)
\item Er hatte einen Hut getragen. (He had worn a hat.)
\item Ich war zu Hause geblieben. (I had stayed home.)
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a grammar exercise for a student learning French. It should have a subsection for answers. It should be an exercise on replacing words with direct object pronouns.

\begin{enumerate}

    \item Il consulte le médecin.
    \item Nous soutenons votre projet.
    \item Ils construisent la maison de leurs rêves.
    \item J'ouvre la porte.

    \item Il accepte les résultats.
    \item Nous comprenons leur décision.
    \item Tu visites le château de Fontainebleau.
    \item Elle étudie sa leçon.

\item Il le consulte.
\item Nous le soutenons.
\item Ils la construisent.
\item Je l'ouvre.
\item Elle la conduit.

\item Nous la comprenons.

instruction: Give me a grammar exercise for a student learning French. It should be an exercise on using the gérondif tense. It should be a with Answer.
response:
Mettre au gérondif les verbes suivants:
\begin{enumerate}
    \item C'est en (faire) de l'exercice que vous serez en forme.
    \item Elle chante en (prendre) une douche.
    \item Il s'est tordu la cheville en (jouer) au volley.
    \item Ils ont bronzé en (faire) du ski de fond.
    \item Il l'a invitée à dîner en (savoir) que cela lui ferait plaisir.
    \item En (aller) en Inde, il a fait escale en Allemagne.
    \item Tout en (se plaindre), elle avait l'air satisfaite.
    \item Ils ont découvert la basilique de Lisieux en (visiter) la Normandie.
    \item J'ai rencontré un ami en (arriver) à Paris.
    \item Il a tout perdu en (parier) tous les jours au casino.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item faisant
\item prenant
\item jouant
\item faisant
\item sachant
\item allant
\item se plaignant
\item visitant
\item arrivant
\item pariant
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a grammar exercise for a student learning French. It should be an exercise on using the subjunctive. It should be a with Answer.
response:
Mettre les propositions subordonnées au subjonctif.
\begin{enumerate}
    \item Il faut que vous (aller)          voir ce film.
    \item Il est essentiel que vous (arriver)          avant la fin de la semaine.
    \item Il est impensable que nous (accepter)          ces conditions.
    \item Il est possible que nous (voyager)          cet été.
    \item Il est important qu'il (être)          à l'heure.
    \item Il vaut mieux que nous (ne rien dire)          .
    \item Il est regrettable que ses enfants (habiter)          si loin.
    \item Il est dommage que vous (vendre)          votre maison de campagne.
    \item Il est indispensable qu'elle (suivre)          un cours d'informatique.
    \item Il est rare que nous (emporter)          du travail à la maison.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item alliez
\item arriviez
\item acceptions
\item voyagions
\item soit
\item ne disions rien
\item habitent
\item vendiez
\item suive
\item emportions
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a grammar exercise for a student learning French. It should be an exercise on the futur immédiat. It should be a with Answer.
response:
Mettre les phrases suivantes au futur immédiat:
\begin{enumerate}
    \item Nous achetons une nouvelle machine à laver.
    \item Il prend des vacances cet automne.
    \item Vous investissez au Japon.
    \item Elle a vingt ans.
    \item Cette agence promeut cette marchandise.
    \item Il est président.
    \item Nous choisissons un cadeau.
    \item Tu dînes au restaurant.
    \item Ils déménagent en janvier.
    \item Elle travaille au centre-ville.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Nous allons acheter une nouvelle machine à laver.
\item Il va prendre des vacances cet automne.
\item Vous allez investir au Japon.
\item Elle va avoir vingt ans.
\item Cette agence va promouvoir cette marchandise.
\item Il va être président.
\item Nous allons choisir un cadeau.
\item Tu vas dîner au restaurant.
\item Ils vont déménager en janvier.
\item Elle va travailler au centre-ville.
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a grammar exercise for a student learning French. It should be an exercise on negative form. It should be a with Answer.
response:

    \item Nous étudions l'arabe.
    \item Il maigrit en vacances.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Il n'encourage pas ses employés.
\item Ils ne visitent pas le musée.
\item Tu ne gagnes pas à la loterie.
\item Elle n'enlève pas son chapeau.
\item Vous n'exprimez pas vos opinions.
\item Tu ne pèses pas les fruits.
\item Il ne danse pas la valse.
\item Vous ne corrigez pas les copies des étudiants.
\item Nous n'étudions pas l'arabe.

instruction: Give me a fill in the blank exercise for a student learning Dutch. It should be an exercise on using appropriate words.
response:
Complete the following sentences, using \textit{gewoon}, \textit{hoor} or \textit{natuurlijk} as appropriate.

\begin{enumerate}
\item Your boyfriend is going on a three-day break with the lads, and you remind him in a friendly way that he must phone you:\\
Je moet me wel bellen, \_\_ .
\item He has forgotten to phone you before on these occasions, so this time you remind him with greater urgency:\\
Je moet me wel bellen, \_\_ .
\item You tell your junior colleague not to worry about the fact that the door to your office is often closed and to just walk in:\\
Je moet \_\_\_ naar binnen lopen, \_\_\_ .
\item The door to the secretary's office is always closed and she doesn't like it when you just walk in.\\
She reminds you to knock first: Ja, je moet wel even aankloppen, \_\_\_.
\item You encourage your friend to be decisive and go ahead with her plan.\\
After all, it's not a big deal: Je moet het \_\_\_ doen.
\item You strongly advise your friend to go ahead with it: \_\_\_ moet je het doen.
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a fill in the blank exercise for a student learning Dutch. It should have a subsection for answers. It should be an exercise on completing dialogues.
response:
Complete the dialogues:
\begin{enumerate}

Marja - Nee, bier. \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_?
\item Peter - Jij zoekt toch het station?\\
Helen - Nee, het postkantoor. \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_?
\item Annie - Jij maakt toch de soep?\\
Raymond - Nee, het slaatje. \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_?
\item Meneer Vogel - U schrijft toch kinderboeken?\\
Mevrouw de Loo - Nee, romans. Wat \underline{\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_} u?
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Hanny - Jij drinkt toch wijn?\\
Marja - Nee, bier. Wat drink jij?
\item Peter - Jij zoekt toch het station?\\
Helen - Nee, het postkantoor. Wat zoek jij?
\item Annie - Jij maakt toch de soep?\\
Raymond - Nee, het slaatje. Wat maak jij?
\item Meneer Vogel - U schrijft toch kinderboeken?\\
Mevrouw de Loo - Nee, romans. Wat schrijft u?
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a fill in the blank exercise for a student learning Dutch. It should be an exercise on time measures. It should be an exercise involving mini-dialogues.
response:
Complete these mini-dialogues using the information given in brackets.

\begin{enumerate}
\item Hoelang werk je nu in Nederland? (2 weeks and you think that's a short time)\\
Nog maar net. Ik werk hier \_\_\_ .
\item Hoelang sta je al op me te wachten? (10 minutes and you think that's a long time)\\
Daar ben je eindelijk. Ik sta hier \_\_\_ .
\item Hoelang zijn we nu samen? (3 years, 5 months and 23 days, to be exact. You are fairly neutral about this)\\
We zijn samen, om precies te zijn.
\item Hoelang leer je al Nederlands? Je spreekt 'tal zo goed. (2 years, neutral)\\
Dank je. Ik spreek \_\_\_\_ Nederlands.
\item Hoelang woon je hier al? (8 months, not a long time)\\
Niet zo lang, hoor. Ik woon \_\_\_\_\_.
\item Moet jij niet werken? Hoelang zit je hier nu al koffie te drinken? (only 2 hours)\\
Eh \_\_\_\_ ik zit hier. Ik heb zeeën van tijd.
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a fill in the blank exercise for a student learning Spanish. It should have a subsection for answers. It should be an exercise on compound past tense.
response:
Complete the following sentences with the proper compound past tense.

\begin{enumerate}
    \item ¡Los piratas \_\_\_ tesoro! The pirates have found the treasure!
    \item Grecia \_\_\_ el mejor equipo del torneo. Greece has been the best team in the tournament.
    \item Yo \_\_\_ durante el año. I've been working hard during the year.
    \item Nosotros \_\_\_ en autobús. We've traveled by bus.
    \item Tú \_\_\_ suerte. You've had luck.
    \item Sevilla \_\_\_ más bonita de lo que esperaba. Sevilla has been more beautiful than what I expected.
    \item Vosotras \_\_\_ cerca del aeropuerto. You've been close to the airport.
    \item Yo \_\_\_ muchos plátanos. I've eaten a lot of bananas.
    \item Mis padres \_\_\_ con mi profesor. My parents have spoken with my professor.
    \item \_\_\_ mucho en Toledo. It has rained a lot in Toledo.
    \item Maria \_\_\_ una buena profesora. Maria has been a good professor.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
    \item ¡Los piratas han encontrado el tesoro!
    \item Grecia ha sido el mejor equipo del torneo.
    \item He estado trabajando duro durante el año.
    \item Hemos viajado en autobús.
    \item Ha habido suerte.
    \item Sevilla ha sido más bella de lo que esperaba.
    \item Has estado cerca del aeropuerto.
    \item He comido muchos plátanos.
    \item Mis padres han hablado con mi profesor.
    \item Ha llovido mucho en Toledo.
    \item Maria ha sido una buena profesora.
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a fill in the blanks exercise for a student learning German. It should be an exercise on auxiliary and action verbs. It should be a with Answer.
response:
Use the correct form of the auxiliary and action verbs in the following sentences.

\begin{enumerate}
\item (laufen) Wir \_\_\_ den ganzen Tag \_\_\_\_. \\
   (We walked all day.)
\item (kaufen) Sie hat gestern ein neues Kleid \_\_\_\_. \\
   (She bought a new dress yesterday.)
\item (kochen) Hans \_\_\_ heute morgen Pasta \_\_\_\_. \\
   (Hans cooked pasta this morning.)
\item (lieben) Ich \_\_\_ diese Schuhe \_\_\_\_. \\
   (I loved those shoes.)
\item (reisen) Wir \_\_\_ letzten Monat durch Europa \_\_\_\_. \\

   (You made a mistake.)

\item (bleiben) Wir \_\_\_ zu Hause \_\_\_\_. \\
   (We stayed at home.)
\item (anrufen) Ich \_\_\_ dein Büro \_\_\_\_. \\
   (I called your office.)
\item (send) Hans \_\_\_ Anne ein Jahr lang jeden Tag Blumen \_\_\_\_. \\
    (Hans sent Anne flowers every week for three years.)
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}

\item sind, gereist
\item hast, gemacht

instruction: Give me a fill in the blank exercise for a student learning German. It should have a subsection for answers. It should be an exercise on choosing the correct word or phrase.
response:
Complete the sentences below with the correct word or phrase from the two provided in parentheses.

\begin{enumerate}
\item Wir sehen die Kinder \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ Garten. (in dem, in den)
\item Die Zeitungen waren \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ Heft. (neben dem, neben das)
\item Vater ging langsam \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ Tür. (an der, an die)
\item Die Kinder laufen \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ Haus. (hinter dem, hinter das)
\item Mein Vetter sitzt \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ Frau. (neben seiner, neben seine)
\item Die Jungen spielen \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ Park. (im, in den)
\item Er stellt die Vase \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ Klavier. (auf dem, auf das)
\item Was hängt \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ Tisch? (über dem, über den)
\item Sie läuft \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ Küche. (in der, in die)
\item Wer steht \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ Ecke? (an der, an die)
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Wir sehen die Kinder in dem Garten. \\
(We see the children in the garden.)
\item Die Zeitungen waren neben dem Heft. \\
(The newspapers were next to the book.)
\item Vater ging langsam an die Tür. \\
(Father went slowly to the door.)
\item Die Kinder laufen hinter das Haus. \\
(The children ran behind the house.)
\item Mein Vetter sitzt neben seiner Frau. \\
(My cousin is sitting next to his wife.)
\item Die Jungen spielen im Park. \\
(The boys play in the garden.)
\item Er stellt die Vase auf das Klavier. \\
(He places the vase on the piano.)
\item Was hängt über dem Tisch? \\
(What's hanging above the table?)
\item Sie läuft in die Küche. \\
(She runs into the kitchen.)
\item Wer steht an der Ecke? \\
(Who's standing on the corner?)
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a fill in the blank exercise for a student learning Dutch. It should be a with Answers. It should be an exercise involving an example. It should be an exercise on using die or dat.
response:
Complete using die or dat.\\
Fill in the correct form of the word between brackets.\\
For example:\\
Wil je in die stoel zitten?\\
Nee, ... stoel zit ... (lekker) --> Nee, deze stoel zit lekkerder.\\

\begin{enumerate}
\item Vind je dit boek moeilijk?\\
Nee, ik vind ... boek ... (moeilijk).
\item Vind je deze gele broek mooi?\\
Nee, ik vind ... rode broek ... (mooi).
\item Wil je deze krant hebben?\\
Nee, ik vind ... krant ... (interessant).
\item Vind je dit artikel saai?\\
Nee, ik vind ... artikel ... (saai).
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Vind je dit boek moeilijk?\\
Nee, ik vind dat boek moeilijker.
\item Vind je deze gele broek mooi?\\
Nee, ik vind die rode broek mooier.
\item Wil je deze krant hebben?\\
Nee, ik vind die krant interessanter.
\item Vind je dit artikel saai?\\
Nee, ik vind dat artikel saaier.
\end{enumerate}

response:

instruction: Give me a combination of a short answer exercise and a fill in the blank exercise for a student learning Dutch. It should have a subsection for answers. It should be an exercise on politeness and irritation.
response:
\begin{enumerate}
\item Some friends are coming over for dinner. You're welcoming them in Dutch. Follow the instructions.
    \begin{enumerate}[label=\roman*.]
    \item They knock on the door. Greet them and invite them in.
    \item Invite them to take their coat off.
    \item Suggest that they sit down.
    \end{enumerate}
\item In the following sentences, does maar indicate that the speaker is being polite or irritated?
    \begin{enumerate}[label=\roman*.]
    \item Geef je jas maar aan mij!
    \item Kom maar met me mee.
    \end{enumerate}
\item In the following sentences, does toch indicate that the speaker is being polite or irritated?
    \begin{enumerate}[label=\roman*.]
    \item Geef dat boek toch hier!
    \item Kom toch met me mee.
    \end{enumerate}
\item Fill in maar or toch.
    \begin{enumerate}[label=\roman*.]
    \item Je hebt al genoeg gedaan. Ga ..... naar huis. (Your boss tells you that you can go home).
    \item Blijf ..... stil zitten! (A father to his daughter, who has been annyoing him).
    \item Drink je drankje .... op. (A husband to his wife, at a party he wants to leave).
    \item Geef mij ..... een biertje. (Your answer to your host's question what you'd like to drink).
    \end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item \begin{enumerate}[label=\roman*.]
    \item Hallo, kom maar binnen.
    \item Doe je jas maar uit.
    \item Ga maar zitten.
    \end{enumerate}
\item \begin{enumerate}[label=\roman*.]
    \item Irritated
    \item Polite
    \end{enumerate}
\item \begin{enumerate}[label=\roman*.]
    \item Irritated
    \item Polite
    \end{enumerate}
\item \begin{enumerate}[label=\roman*.]
    \item maar
    \item toch
    \item maar
    \item maar
    \end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a short answer exercise for a student learning Dutch. It should have a subsection for answers. It should be an exercise on a phone conversation.
response:
Frouke: Met Frouke van den Broek.\\
Dinie: Dag Frouke, met Dinie Heijermans.\\
Zeg, ik heb eigenlijk een afspraak met je voor maandag, maar ik moet dat helaas afzeggen.\\
Kan ik voor een andere keer afspreken?\\
Frouk: Ja, natuurlijk. Komt morgen je goed uit?\\
Dinie: Nee, dat komt mij niet zo goed uit. Donderdag is beter.\\
Frouke: Om tien uur?\\
Dinie: Ja dat is goed. Dan spreken we donderdag om tien uur af.\\
Frouke: Tot dan.\\
Dinie: Ja, tot dan.\\

Answer the following questions about the phone conversation between Dinie and Frouke in English, but answer the third and fourth in Dutch.
\begin{enumerate}
\item What does Frouke say when she answers the phone? (give the English translation)
\item Why does Dinie phone her homeopath?
\item Which expression indicates that Frouke readily agrees to this?
\item How does Frouke ask whether tomorrow will suit Dinie? (give the Dutch expression)
\item Does that suit Dinie?
\item When do they agree to meet?
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Frouke says: Hello, speaking with Frouke van den Broek.
\item Dinie phones her homeopath because she has to cancel her appointment with Frouke for Monday.
\item Frouke says: Ja, natuurlijk.
\item Frouke asks: Komt morgen je goed uit?
\item No
\item They agree to meet on Thursday at ten o'clock.
\end{enumerate}

Barkeeper: Jazeker. Zeg't maar. Cola? Wijntje? Pilsje?

Berend: Geeft u mij maar een pilsje.

Berend: Ik wil graag een uitsmijter.
Annie: Ja voor mij ook.

instruction: Give me a combination of a word problem and an arithmetic exercise for a 4th grade student learning mathematics. It should be an exercise on bead calculation. It should be a with Answer.
response:
Nasreen has a packet of coloured beads. The packet contains 5 orange beads, 5 red beads, and 10 blue beads. Nasreen says, "Half the beads are blue." She is correct. Explain how you know.

\subsection*{Answers}
To determine if Nasreen is correct, we first calculate the total number of beads:
\[
5 \text{ (orange)} + 5 \text{ (red)} + 10 \text{ (blue)} = 20 \text{ beads}.
\]
Next, we find half of the total number of beads:
\[
\frac{20}{2} = 10 \text{ beads}.
\]
Since there are 10 blue beads, which is half of the total, Nasreen is correct.

instruction: Give me a combination of a spelling exercise and a meaning exercise for a student learning Spanish. It should be an exercise involving transcription. It should be a with Answer. It should be an exercise in Spanish.

Give me a combination of a dialogue completion exercise and a grammar exercise for a student learning Spanish. It should have a subsection for answers. It should be an exercise on using the verbs "Estar" and "Ser".
response:
Complete this dialogue with the right form of the verb “Estar” or “Ser.”  

Pablo: Buenos días, ¿ \_\_ aquí Maria? (Hello, is Maria there?)
La mamá de María: No, ella no \_\_. \_\_ en el doctor con su papá. Ellos \_\_ enfermos. ¿Quieres dejarle un mensaje? ¿Tú \_\_ ? (No, she's not here. She went to the doctor with her dad. They are both sick. Do you want to leave a message for her? You are…?)
Pablo: Pablo. \_\_ Pablo. Sí, muchas gracias. (Pablo. I am Pablo. Yes, thank you very much.)

\subsection*{Answers}
Pablo: Buenos días, ¿está aquí María? (Hello, is Maria there?)  
La mamá de María: No, ella no está. Está en el doctor con su papá. Ellos están enfermos. ¿Quieres dejarle un mensaje? ¿Tú eres…? (No, she's not here. She went to the doctor with her dad. They are both sick. Do you want to leave a message for her? You are…?)
Pablo: Pablo. Soy Pablo. Sí, muchas gracias. (Pablo. I am Pablo. Yes, thank you very much.)

instruction: Give me a combination of a dialogue exercise and a grammar exercise for a student learning Spanish. It should be an exercise on demonstrative pronouns. It should be a with Answer.
response:
Complete the following dialogue with the corresponding demonstrative pronouns.  
\_\_\_\_ es mi familia. Mi madre se llama Rebeca y mi papá Alberto. Tengo dos hermanos. \_\_\_\_ que está sentado se llama David, y el que \_\_\_\_ jugando es el menor, Pedro. \_\_\_\_ que están en el jardín son mis primos Diego y Camila. \_\_\_\_ que están en el patio son nuestros perros, Lancer y Claudio. Bueno, \_\_\_\_ es toda mi familia. ¡Que tengas un buen día!

\subsection*{Answers}
Esta es mi familia. Mi madre se llama Rebeca y mi papá Alberto. Tengo dos hermanos. Ese que está sentado se llama David y el que está jugando es el menor, Pedro. Aquellos que están en el jardín son mis primos Diego y Camila. Esos que están en el patio son nuestros perros, Lancer y Claudio. Bueno, esta es toda mi familia. ¡Que tengas un buen día!

instruction: Give me a combination of an activity and an experiment exercise for a 2nd grade student learning science. It should be an exercise involving a cardboard box. It should be an activity involving light observation.
response:
\begin{enumerate}
  \item Find a small cardboard box. For example, a cereal packet or a shoe box.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Cut a small flap in the end of the box. This flap will act as a ‘window’ that can be opened and closed.
    \item Make a small hole in one side of the box for you to peep through.
    \item Put some small coloured objects in the box.
    \item Wrap the box in black paper or a cloth to keep out the light. Cut the same flap and hole in the wrapping.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Open the flap and then peep through the hole. What can you see?
  \item Record what you observe.
  \item Predict what will happen when you close the flap.
  \item Close the flap and peep through the small hole again. What can you see?
  \item Record what you observe.
  \item Talk with your group about what you found out.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Try to explain it.
    \item Share what you found out with the class.
  \end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a combination of an activity, an investigation, and a group discussion exercise for a 5th grade student learning science. It should have a subsection for materials. It should be an exercise on shadows. It should be an activity involving predictions.
response:
\begin{enumerate}
  \item Play with the torch and one object against a sheet of paper to act as a screen where you can observe the shadow.
  \item Predict what will happen to the shadow length as you change the distance of the object from the torch.
  \item Write down your predictions.
  \item Observe what happens to the shadow on the screen when the light source (torch) and the screen stay in the same position, but the object is moved further and further from the light source.
  \item Draw the shadows on the screen when the object is in at least five different positions (five different distances from the torch).
  \item Measure the distance each time.
  \item Record the measurements in a table like this one:
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Observation
    \item Distance from source (cm)
    \item Length of shadow (cm)
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Discuss your results with your group. Compare your results with your predictions.
  \item Present your results as a line graph.
  \item Try to reach a conclusion and make a generalised statement about shadow length and distance from the light source.
  \item Share your group's ideas and graph with the class. Look at the graphs of other groups and listen to their ideas.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Materials}
\begin{itemize}
  \item Torch
  \item A3 or A2 paper
\end{itemize}

instruction: Give me a combination of a class activity, a group discussion, and an investigation exercise for a 6th grade student learning science. It should be an exercise on changes of state and temperature. It should be an exercise on hardness.

    \item a change of temperature, or

  \item Collect the items needed for your chosen activity.
  \item Discuss with your group:
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item how you will investigate the change
    \item how you will record the results.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Write out the plan for the steps of your investigation and include your prediction of what you think will happen. Show your plan to your teacher.
  \item Carry out the activity, observing change and recording your observations in words and/or drawings.
  \item When the changes have ended, look at your results.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Discuss them with your group.
    \item Come to a conclusion about what they tell you about the change you investigated: was it reversible or was it irreversible?
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Share your results with the class and explain why you have come to your conclusion.
  \item Listen to the results and conclusions of other groups and ask questions if you do not understand or agree.
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a combination of an activity, an experiment, a discussion exercise, and a partner activity for a 4th grade student learning science. It should have a subsection for materials. The exercise should contain some kind of a graphic component (illustration, diagram, table, etc). It should be an exercise on sound. It should be an activity on sound traveling through liquids.
response:
You will need: a balloon, a ticking watch, and a timer, paper (or Workbooks) and a pen or pencil.
\begin{itemize}
\item Fill the balloon with water and place it beside your head so that it touches your ear.
\item Ask your partner to hit the watch, clock or timer on the other side of the balloon, so that you can hear it.
\item Listen carefully and compare what you hear this time with the first time.
\item Swap with your partner and repeat the activity.
\item Discuss the observations you both made and come to a conclusion about sound travelling through water.
\end{itemize}

instruction: Give me a grammar exercise for a student learning Spanish. It should have a subsection for answers. It should be an exercise on correcting grammatical errors.

(Good morning! I am Antonia. I'm 27. I'm from Chicago, but now I live in a Mexican city called Tijuana. I'm a shop assistant and I work in a clothing store.)  

\subsection*{Answers}
¡Buenos días! Soy Antonia. Tengo veintisiete años. Soy de Chicago, pero ahora vivo en una ciudad de México que se llama Tijuana. Soy asistente de ventas y trabajo en una tienda de ropa.

instruction: Give me a grammar exercise for a student learning French. It should be an exercise on replacing demonstrative adjectives with demonstrative pronouns. It should be a with Answer.
response:
Remplacer l'adjectif démonstratif par le pronom démonstratif.

\begin{enumerate}
    \item Cette robe est rose. Cette robe est blanche.
    \item Ces écrivains sont inconnus. Ces écrivains sont célèbres.
    \item Cet oncle est jeune. Cet oncle est plus âgé.
    \item Ce rendez-vous est trop tôt. Ce rendez-vous est trop tard.
    \item Ce roman est un best-seller. Ce roman est épuisé.
    \item Cet ordinateur est vieux. Cet ordinateur est le dernier modèle.
    \item Cette peinture est trop claire. Cette peinture est trop foncée.
    \item Ces articles sont bien écrits. Ces articles sont mal écrits.
    \item Cette valise est légère. Cette valise est lourde.
    \item Ces arguments sont bons. Ces arguments sont nuls.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}

\begin{enumerate}
    \item Celle-ci est rose. Celle-là est blanche.
    \item Ceux-ci sont inconnus. Ceux-là sont célèbres.
    \item Celui-ci est jeune. Celui-là est plus âgé.
    \item Celui-ci est trop tôt. Celui-là est trop tard.
    \item Celui-ci est un best-seller. Celui-là est épuisé.
    \item Celui-ci est vieux. Celui-là est le dernier modèle.
    \item Celle-ci est trop claire. Celle-là est trop foncée.
    \item Ceux-ci sont bien écrits. Ceux-là sont mal écrits.
    \item Celle-ci est légère. Celle-là est lourde.
    \item Ceux-ci sont bons. Ceux-là sont nuls.
\end{enumerate}

\item Morgen gehen wir \textbf{in die Bibliothek}. (Tomorrow we are going to the library.) \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item Der Student sucht \textbf{ein Heft und zwei Bleistifte}. (The student is looking for a notebook and two pens.) \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item \textbf{Am Donnerstag} fliegen sie nach New York. (On Thursday we're flying to New York.) \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item Sabine findet \textbf{eine graue Bluse}. (Sabine finds a gray blouse.)
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}

\item Wann fliegen sie nach New York?

\begin{enumerate}

    \item Suben los impuestos: \_\_\_\_\_\_ (Taxes have gone up.)
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Se han fugado setenta presos.
\item Ha muerto el escritor.
\item Ha acabado la huelga de transporte.
\item América ha quedado campeón de la liga.
\item Han subido los impuestos.
\end{enumerate}

\item hält
\end{enumerate}

Give me a combination of a writing exercise and a question and answer exercise for a student learning Dutch. It should have a subsection for answers. It should be an exercise involving an example. It should be an exercise on asking for information and giving directions.
response:
Practice asking for information about where something is, using the word waar, and giving simple directions. Identify the signs for the following places and give answers about where they are. For example: Waar is het internetcafe? Het internetcafe is aan de rechterkant.

\begin{enumerate}
\item het ziekenhuis
\item het zwembad
\item het station
\item het internetcafe
\item het postkantoor
\item het wisselkantoor
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Waar is het ziekenhuis?\\
Het ziekenhuis is aan de linkerkant.
\item Waar is het zwembad?\\
Het zwembad is aan de rechterkant.
\item Waar is het station?\\
Het station is rechtdoor.
\item Waar is het internetcafe?\\
Het internetcafe is aan de rechterkant.
\item Waar is het postkantoor?\\
Het postkantoor is aan de linkerkant.
\item Waar is het wisselkantoor?\\
Het wisselkantoor is rechtdoor.
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a combination of a short answer exercise and a dialogue exercise for a student learning Dutch. It should have multiple steps. It should be an exercise that requires some reading comprehension. It should be an exercise involving the writing of sentences.

\begin{enumerate}
\item Ask Jan what he is going to do on the days listed in his diary and also provide his response. Say it out loud first and then write it down. Make sure you alter the form of the main verb as necessary.
\item Marjan is asking you about Jan's activities. She wants to know what he is going to do on Saturday afternoon and Sunday morning. Make a mini-dialogue with her questions and your answers.\\
\end{enumerate}

\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a translation exercise for a student learning French. It should be an exercise on using idiomatic expressions with possessive pronouns. It should be an exercise on using the form tu. It should be a with Answer.
response:

\begin{enumerate}

    \item My friend René is not at ease among his peers.
    \item His young dog has been acting up again!
    \item Their granddaughter has been acting up again in school!
    \item Cheers! It's your birthday.
    \item You are going to lose everything if you don't make an effort!
    \item If he does not contribute his share, the presentation will be a disaster!

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}

\item Mon ami René n'est pas à l'aise parmi les siens.
\item Son jeune chien a encore fait des siennes!
\item Leur petite-fille a encore fait des siennes à l'école!
\item À la tienne! C'est ton anniversaire.
\item Tu vas tout perdre si tu n'y mets pas du tien!
\item S'il n'y met pas du sien, la présentation sera un désastre!
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}

\item Reposons-nous sur le banc!

\item Ne soyez pas en retard!
\item Allons en Italie!
\item Ferme la porte!
\item Attendez-moi!

\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a writing exercise for a 4th grade student learning English. It should be an exercise on planning and writing about an island.
response:
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item Use these questions to help you plan a piece of writing about the island. Answer the questions in note form.
    \begin{enumerate}[label=\roman*.]
    \item What can you see?
    Think about the trees and bushes around you. Can you see hills? Can you still see the sea? Write words and phrases to describe what you see. Use interesting adjectives.
    \item What do you do?
    Think about why you are on the island. Are you looking for the treasure? Write words and phrases to describe what you do. Use interesting verbs.
    \item How do you feel?
    Think about the fact you are all alone. Are you frightened? Are you excited about looking for the treasure? Write words and phrases to describe how you feel. Use interesting adjectives.
    \end{enumerate}

\item Write three paragraphs using your notes. You can use your exercise book to continue writing. Remember:
    \begin{itemize}

instruction: Give me a grammar exercise for a student learning German. It should be an exercise on choosing the correct gender. It should be a with Answer.
response:

For example, when presented with the word Vater, you would say der Vater because Vater (father) is masculine. Write the correct article on the line.

\begin{enumerate}
\item Mantel (coat) \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item Ausstellung (exhibition) \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item Gelächter (laughter) \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item Klasse (class) \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item Brunnen (well, source of water) \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item Sprache (language) \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item Männchen (little man) \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item Prüfung (exam) \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item Wissenschaft (science) \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item Essen (eating) \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item der Mantel
\item die Ausstellung
\item das Gelächter
\item die Klasse
\item der Brunnen
\item die Sprache
\item das Männchen
\item die Prüfung
\item die Wissenschaft
\item das Essen
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a grammar exercise for a student learning Spanish. It should be an exercise on indirect object pronouns. It should be a with Answer.

response:
Create questions using “hay” (see the example below).  
Example: Un perro/jardín
¿Hay un perro en el jardín? (Is there a dog in the garden?)  

\begin{enumerate}
    \item Una habitación libre/ hotel. (a free room/hotel)
    \item Azúcar/café. (sugar/coffee)
    \item Las clases de baile/gimnasio. (dance classes/gym)
    \item Un león/zoológico (a lion/zoo)
    \item Baños/aquí. (toilets/here)
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item ¿Hay una habitación libre en el hotel?
\item ¿Hay azúcar para el café?
\item ¿Hay clases de baile en el gimnasio?
\item ¿Hay un león en el zoológico?
\item ¿Hay baños aquí?
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a grammar exercise for a student learning French. It should be an exercise on replacing words. It should be a with Answer.
response:

    \item La grand-mère a raconté une histoire aux petits-enfants.
    \item Nous avons fait un cadeau à Marie.
    \item Je ferai parvenir le dossier à Jean dès que possible.
    \item Nous enverrons des fleurs à notre collègue.
    \item Ce théâtre appartient à un ancien comédien.
    \item Est-ce que tu as écrit au rédacteur en chef?
    \item Téléphonez à Louise aussitôt que possible!
    \item Ne mentionnez rien à Odile!
    \item Il annoncera sa décision à ses employés demain.
    \item Il donnera le scénario aux acteurs en fin de journée.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item La grand-mère leur a raconté une histoire.
\item Nous lui avons fait un cadeau.
\item Je lui ferai parvenir le dossier dès que possible.
\item Nous lui enverrons des fleurs.
\item Ce théâtre lui appartient.
\item Est-ce que tu lui as écrit?
\item Téléphonez-lui aussitôt que possible!
\item Ne lui mentionnez rien!
\item Il leur annoncera sa décision demain.
\item Il leur donnera le scénario en fin de journée.
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a grammar exercise for a student learning French. It should be an exercise on present tense verbs. It should be a with Answer.
response:

\begin{enumerate}
    \item Can you swim?
    \item Can he cook?
    \item I don't know where he is.
    \item Can she fill out this form?
    \item She knows Caroline.

    \item It is raining in France.
    \item You must arrive at noon.
    \item He foresees a great improvement.
    \item I see the castle.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}

\begin{enumerate}
    \item Est-ce que tu sais nager?
    \item Est-ce qu'il sait faire la cuisine?
    \item Je ne sais pas où il est.
    \item Est-ce qu'elle peut remplir ce formulaire?
    \item Elle connaît Caroline.
    \item Est-ce que tu sais cette chanson française par cœur?
    \item Il pleut en France.
    \item Tu dois arriver à midi.

\end{enumerate}

Now change the indefinite article of each noun to the definite article.\\

For example, when presented with ein Vater, you would say der Vater to change it to the definite article. (Watch out! This one is trickier. Since masculine and neuter words both take the indefinite article ein, you'll have to recall the rules for determining gender in these cases.)

\begin{enumerate}
\item ein Mantel (coat)
\item eine Lehrerin (teacher)
\item ein Kind (child)
\item ein Bruder (brother)
\item ein Richter (judge)
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item ein Lehrer
\item eine Schauspielerin
\item eine Tasse
\item ein Pilot
\item ein Mädchen
\item der Mantel
\item die Lehrerin
\item das Kind
\item der Bruder
\item der Richter
\end{enumerate}

\item accusative, diese

\item nominative, Wir

\end{enumerate}

response:
Using the pronouns, decide which possessive adjective to use to complete each sentence. For example, when presented with "ich / Sabine findet \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_ Buch," you say, "Sabine findet mein Buch." Sabine finds my book, because "mein" is the possessive adjective form of "ich."\\

Watch out for masculine words in the accusative case! You'll need an –en ending

\begin{enumerate}
\item du / Vater war im Wohnzimmer. \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item sie (sing.) / Ich kenne Mutter. \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item er / Wir sahen Bruder im Theater. \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item wir / Der Franzose kaufte Volkswagen. \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item Sie / Wo ist Vetter? \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item ich / Das sind Bücher. \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item sie (pl.) / Wo ist Haus? \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item ihr / Sind Plätze gut? \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item er / Karl besuchte Onkel in der Hauptstadt. \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\item wir / Das ist ein Geschenk für Lehrerin. \\
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Dein Vater war im Wohnzimmer. \\
(Your father was in the living room.)
\item Ich kenne ihre Mutter. \\
(I know her mother.)
\item Wir sahen seinen Bruder im Theater. \\
(We saw his brother at the theater.)
\item Der Franzose kaufte unseren Volkswagen. \\
(The Frenchman bought our Volkswagen.)
\item Wo ist Ihr Vetter? \\
(Where is your cousin?)
\item Das sind meine Bücher. \\
(Those are my books.)
\item Wo ist ihr Haus? \\
(Where is their house?)
\item Sind eure Plätze gut? \\
(Are your seats [in the theater] good?)
\item Karl besuchte seinen Onkel in der Hauptstadt. \\
(Karl visited his uncle in the capital city.)
\item Das ist ein Geschenk für unsere Lehrerin. \\
(That is a present for our teacher.)
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a short answer exercise for a student learning Dutch. It should have a subsection for answers. It should be an exercise on identifying informal and colloquial language.
response:
\textbf{Dialogue 1: Bij De Delicatessen}\\
Wieteke: Wat zullen we nemen?\\
Gerrit: Ik heb zin in de gevulde burrito's vanavond.\\
Wieteke: Die zijn een beetje duur.\\
Gerrit: Hm ja. De loempia's zijn goedkoper. Zullen we die maar nemen?\\

\textbf{Dialogue 2: In De Restaurant}\\
Wieteke: Neem jij het dagmenu?\\
Gerrit: Ik heb eigenlijk zin in biefstuk, maar dat is minder gezond.\\
Wieteke: Dan neem je het dagmenu toch? Dat vind je toch ook lekker.\\

\textbf{Dialogue 3: In De Sportswinkel}
Mark: Jee, wat een cool T-shirtl\\
Tony: Nee joh. Die daar is toch veel hipper?\\
Mark: Ja, en ook stukken duurder.\\
Tony: Ach man, wat maakt dat nou uit? Dan werk je toch een paar dagen meer in de zomer?\\

\begin{enumerate}
\item Which of the three dialogues is the most informal and colloquial?
\item How can you tell by the language used?
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Dialogue 3 is the most informal and colloquial.
\item The language used is more informal and colloquial, with the use of jee, joh, cool, hipper, stukken duurder en ach man.
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a writing exercise for a student learning Dutch. It should be an exercise on asking questions. It should be a with Answer.
response:
Ask Frans whether he is going to eat in a Chinese restaurant this evening.
For example:
Ga je vanavond in een Chinees restaurant eten?

\begin{enumerate}
\item Ask Frans whether he is going to go dancing the day after tomorrow.
\item Ask him if he is going to play sports (sporten) this evening.
\item Ask him if he is going to work next week.
\item Ask him if he is going to go shopping this afternoon.
\item Ask him if he is going to paint his house next year.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Ga je overmorgen dansen?
\item Ga je vanavond sporten?
\item Ga je volgende week werken?
\item Ga je vanmiddag winkelen?
\item Ga je volgend jaar je huis schilderen?
\end{enumerate}

response:

\begin{enumerate}
    \item Ne parlez pas de ce détail à Zoé!
    \item Elle a emprunté de l'argent à sa sœur.
    \item Je ferai parvenir ce document à votre avocat.
    \item Patrick a raconté ses aventures (f.pl.) à son frère.
    \item Le musicien a envoyé sa nouvelle composition à son agent.
    \item L'ouvrier a donné la lettre au patron.
    \item J'ai demandé la photo au photographe.
    \item Il vendra sa maison à son cousin.
    \item Le médecin a prescrit ce médicament au malade.
    \item Je recommande cet hôtel à tous mes amis.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Ne lui en parlez pas!
\item Elle lui en a emprunté.
\item Je le lui ferai parvenir.
\item Patrick les lui a racontées.
\item Le musicien la lui a envoyée.
\item L'ouvrier la lui a donnée.
\item Je la lui ai demandée.
\item Il la lui vendra.
\item Le médecin le lui a prescrit.
\item Je le leur recommande.
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a grammar exercise for a student learning French. It should be an exercise on pronouns. It should be a with Answer.

\subsection*{Answers}

    \item C'est moi qui prendrai...
    \item C'est vous qui écrirez...
    \item C'est nous qui préparons...
    \item C'est toi qui as fait...

instruction: Give me a translation exercise for a student learning French. It should be an exercise on adjectives. It should be a with Answer.
response:
Traduire les adjectifs entre parenthèses.
\begin{enumerate}
    \item Ta grand-mère est (French)? —Non, elle est (Italian).
    \item Ces fenêtres sont (clean)? —Non, ces fenêtres sont (dirty).
    \item Sa femme est (blond)? —Non, elle est (redhead).
    \item Il porte ses chaussures (black)? —Non, il porte des chaussures (navy blue).
    \item C'est une situation (serious)? —Oui, c'est une situation très (serious).
    \item C'est une histoire (tragic)? —Non, c'est une histoire (funny).
    \item C'est un (long) voyage? —Non, c'est assez (short).
    \item Votre projet est (ambitious). —Non, c'est la directrice qui est (ambitious).
    \item Ses idées sont (good)? —Oui, ses idées sont (better) que les nôtres.
    \item Ton travail est (boring)? —Non, mon travail est très (interesting).
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Ta grand-mère est française? —Non, elle est italienne.
\item Ces fenêtres sont propres? —Non, ces fenêtres sont sales.
\item Sa femme est blonde? —Non, elle est rousse.
\item Il porte ses chaussures noires? —Non, il porte des chaussures bleu marine.
\item C'est une situation sérieuse? —Oui, c'est une situation très sérieuse.
\item C'est une histoire tragique? —Non, c'est une histoire amusante.
\item C'est un long voyage? —Non, c'est assez court.
\item Votre projet est ambitieux? —Non, c'est la directrice qui est ambitieuse.
\item Ses idées sont bonnes? —Oui, ses idées sont meilleures que les nôtres.
\item Ton travail est ennuyeux? —Non, mon travail est très intéressant.
\end{enumerate}

The scales below weigh items up to 1 kg. Label them with the weight of each fruit. What is the total weight of all the fruits? Write this in three different ways:

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Label each scale with the corresponding weight of the fruit.
\item Calculate the total weight of all the fruits.
\item Express the total weight in grams, kilograms, and ounces.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A scale with a dial indicating a weight of 150 g and an apple placed on it. [STPDGM]
[STRDGM] A scale with a dial indicating a weight of 300 g and a banana placed on it. [STPDGM]
[STRDGM] A scale with a dial indicating a weight of 600 g and an orange placed on it. [STPDGM]
[STRDGM] A scale with a dial indicating a weight of 400 g and a pear placed on it. [STPDGM]

instruction: Give me a writing exercise for a 3rd grade student learning English. It should be an exercise involving an example.
response:
You are going to write an index from a book called The Planets. Read the names of the planets that go around the sun. Then, in the book, you can find information about the different planets on the following pages. Finally, make an index for the book. The first entry has been done to help you.

\subsection*{Example}
Mercury:
Mercury is the smallest planet in our solar system and the closest one to the Sun. It's a rocky planet with a surface covered in craters, like our Moon. Because it's so close to the Sun, Mercury has extremely hot days and freezing cold nights.

response:

    \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|}
    \hline
    \textbf{Tense} & \textbf{to talk} & \textbf{to help} & \textbf{to come} & \textbf{to eat} \\
    \hline
    Present & talk &  &  &  \\
    \hline
    Past & talked &  &  &  \\
    \hline
    Present Perfect & have talked &  &  &  \\
    \hline
    Past Perfect & had talked &  &  &  \\
    \hline
    \end{tabular}

\item Use each of these tenses in a sentence of your own.
    \begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*.]
        \item was clearing \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
        \item had known \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_
    \end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a question and answer exercise for a student learning Dutch. It should be an exercise involving an example. It should have multiple steps.
response:
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Wat vind je belangrijker? What do you think is more important?\\
Say what you find more important by answering the questions following the example:\\
Wat vind je belangrijker, je vrije tijd of je werk?\\
Ik vind mijn vrije tijd belangrijker.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*.]
\item Wat vind je belangrijker, kletsen of werken?
\item Wat vind je belangrijker, veel vrije tijd of veel geld?
\item Wat vind je belangrijker, reizen of veel met je vriend(in) doen?
\item Wat vind je belangrijker, je baan of je partner?
\end{enumerate}

\item Wat doe je liever? What would you rather do?
Give your preferences by answering the following questions following the example:
Werk je liever door, of ga je liever naar huis?
Ik ga liever naar huis.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*.]
\item Ga je liever naar het theater, of ga je liever naar de kroeg?
\item Ga je liever naar de stad, of blijf je liever thuis?
\item Werk je liever drie of vijf dagen per week?
\item Ga je liever op vakantie met de motor of met de auto?
\end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a writing exercise for a student learning Dutch. It should have multiple steps. It should be an exercise involving an example.
response:
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item You're going on holiday with a friend. S/he is telling you about their habits. Say if you think these are problems or not: Ja, dat vind ik een probleem. / Nee, dat vind ik geen probleem.
    \begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*.]
    \item Ik doe graag niets. Vind je dat een probleem?
    \item Ik ben niet erg sportief. Vind je dat een probleem?
    \item Ik heb niet veel geld. Vind je dat een probleem?
    \item Ik hou van zon en strand. Vind je dat een probleem?
    \end{enumerate}

\item Your friend is asking you which activities you like. Answer his/her questions.
    \begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*.]
    \item Lig je liever op het strand of speel je liever tennis?
    \item Ga je liever naar de kroeg, of ga je liever vroeg naar bed?
    \item Sta je liever vroeg op, of blijf je iever lang in bed liggen?
    \item Eet je liever in een duur restaurant of in de snackbar?
    \end{enumerate}

\item Using the following pair of characteristics, say what you are and aren't, using niet and wel, as in the example.\\
    Example: koppig / geduldig.\\
    Answer: Ik ben niet koppig, maar wel geduldig.
    \begin{enumerate}[label=\arabic*.]
    \item humeurig / vrolijk
    \item egoïstisch / liefhebbend
    \item spiritueel / romantisch
    \item praktisch / sociaal
    \end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a combination of a question writing exercise and an answer writing exercise for a student learning Dutch. It should be a with Answers. It should be an exercise involving an example.
response:
Your partner has written a shopping list and you are checking the items together.
Ask him how much is needed of each of the items listed.
For example:
Hoeveel flessen wijn heb je nodig?
Ik heb drie flessen nodig.
Hoeveel tomaten heb je nodig?
Ik heb een kilo tomaten nodig.

\begin{enumerate}
\item sinaasappels (5)
\item pakken melk (2)
\item flessen bier (12)
\item bloemkolen (1)
\item appels (1 kilo)
\item pakken rijst (4)
\item bonen (2 kilo)
\item druiven (1 pond)
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Hoeveel sinaasappels heb je nodig? - Ik heb vijf sinaasappels nodig.
\item Hoeveel pakken melk heb je nodig? - Ik heb twee pakken melk nodig.
\item Hoeveel flessen bier heb je nodig? - Ik heb twaalf flessen bier nodig.
\item Hoeveel bloemkolen heb je nodig? - Ik heb één bloemkool nodig.
\item Hoeveel appels heb je nodig? - Ik heb één kilo appels nodig.
\item Hoeveel pakken rijst heb je nodig? - Ik heb vier pakken rijst nodig.
\item Hoeveel bonen heb je nodig? - Ik heb twee kilo bonen nodig.
\item Hoeveel druiven heb je nodig? - Ik heb één pond druiven nodig.
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me an activity for a 2nd grade student learning science. It should be an exercise on shadows.
response: Try to find as many shadows as you can in the classroom.

instruction: Give me a combination of a creative activity and an investigation exercise for a 2nd grade student learning science. It should be an exercise on shadows.
response:
\begin{enumerate}
  \item Go outside in the morning.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Stand in an open place where you can see the Sun.
    \item Look for things that have shadows, such as trees or buildings.
    \item Show the things with their shadows.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Measure at least one of the shadows.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Write down its length.
    \item What time of the morning did you look at the shadows? Write down the time on your drawings.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Predict what you will see when you go outside at noon. Write down your prediction.
  \item Go outside as near to noon as you can and stand in the same place as before.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Make a second drawing of the Sun and the same things on the skyline, with their shadows.
    \item Measure the same shadow and record its length.
    \item Write down the time on your drawing.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Compare what you recorded with your prediction.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item What did you observe?
    \item Was it different from your prediction?
    \item Try to explain what you observed.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Predict what you will see when you go outside late in the day. Write down your prediction.
  \item Go outside as late in the day as you can and stand in the same place.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item Make a third drawing of the Sun and the same things on the skyline, with their shadows.
    \item Measure the same shadow and record its length.
    \item Write down the time on your drawing.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Compare what you recorded with your prediction.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
    \item What did you observe?
    \item Was it different from your prediction?
    \item Try to explain what you observed.
  \end{enumerate}
  \item Share your drawings, your measurements, and your explanations with the class.
\end{enumerate}

Round the height of each tower to the nearest 10 metres and then to the nearest 100 metres:

\begin{enumerate}
    \item Lakhta Centre, St Petersburg, 462 metres
    \item Willis Tower, Chicago, 424 metres
    \item Burj Khalifa, Dubai, 828 metres
    \item Petronas Tower 1, Kuala Lumpur, 452 metres
    \item Shanghai Tower, Shanghai, 632 metres
    \item Lotte World Tower, Seoul, 555 metres
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me an estimation exercise for a 3rd grade student learning mathematics. It should have multiple steps.
response: Imagine you have a 5 litre container and a 2 litre bottle. Imagine that you pour 2 litres of water into the large container. Where will the water reach?

instruction: Give me a combination of an algebra exercise and a word problem for a 6th grade student learning mathematics. It should have multiple steps.
response:

\item Express the number of notebooks Linda has in terms of \( u \).

\item If \( u = 4 \), find the number of notebooks Linda has.

instruction: Give me a combination of a group activity and a data collection exercise for a 5th grade student learning mathematics. It should have multiple steps.
response:
Work in a small group.

Think of something you would like to find out about the class – for example: their favorite animal, sport, or food. You could choose one of these ideas but, better still, think of one of your own.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item How will you collect your data?
\item Collect your data.
\item Represent it in a bar line graph with a vertical axis that goes up in intervals of 2.
\item Draw your graph here:
\end{enumerate}

Write some questions on another piece of paper to ask the class about your graph.

instruction: Give me a combination of a creative exercise and an illustration exercise for a 4th grade student learning mathematics. It should have multiple steps.
response:
Use different colors to show ways of dividing a square in half. How many ways can you find?

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item Draw a line \_\_\_\_\_ to divide the square in half.
\item Draw a line \_\_\_\_\_ to divide the square in half.
\item Draw a \_\_\_\_\_ line from one corner to the opposite corner.
\item Explore other patterns or lines that can divide the square into two equal parts.
\end{enumerate}

[STRDGM] A square. [STPDGM]

instruction: Give me a combination of a word problem and a problem solving exercise for a 5th grade student learning mathematics. It should have multiple steps.

\begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
\item How many girls were at the carnival?
\item How many boys were at the carnival?
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a combination of a puzzle exercise and a word problem for a 6th grade student learning mathematics. It should have multiple steps.
response:

\item Think of a number. Add 2. Multiply by 2. Subtract 4. Divide by 2. Your answer is your start number.
\item Think of a number. Multiply by 3. Add 9. Divide by 3. Subtract 3. Your answer is your start number.
\item Make up a number puzzle like the ones above. Give your puzzle to your friends to try.
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a multiple choice exercise for a student learning Spanish. It should have a subsection for answers.
response:

   \item a
   \item de
   \item hacia
   \end{enumerate}

\item Este camión no llega \_\_ el centro.
   \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
   \item hasta
   \item hacia
   \item a
   \end{enumerate}

\item Para ver esa estrella hay que mirar \_\_ el este.
   \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
   \item de
   \item hacia
   \item desde
   \end{enumerate}

\item El río Amazonas fluye \_\_ el este.
   \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
   \item hacia
   \item de
   \item desde
   \end{enumerate}

\item ¿Cómo se llega \_\_ el estadio?
   \begin{enumerate}[label=\alph*.]
   \item hasta
   \item a
   \item hacia
   \end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Hacia, a
\item Hasta
\item Hacia
\item Desde
\item Hasta
\end{enumerate}

instruction: Give me a translation exercise for a student learning French. It should have a subsection for answers.
response:

instruction: Give me a translation exercise for a student learning French. It should have a subsection for answers.
response:
Traduire les phrases suivantes:
\begin{enumerate}
    \item They spent a month in China.
    \item She fainted.
    \item They kissed each other.
    \item They had fun at the party.
    \item She took the suitcases down.
    \item He brushed his teeth.
    \item He woke up tired.
    \item They wrote each other regularly.
    \item Anna stopped for ten minutes.
    \item He flipped the omelette.
\end{enumerate}

\subsection*{Answers}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Ils (Elles) ont passé un mois en Chine.
\item Elle s'est évanouie.
\item Ils se sont embrassés.
\item Ils se sont amusés (Elles se sont amusées) à la soirée.
\item Elle a descendu les valises.
\item Il s'est brossé les dents.
\item Il s'est réveillé fatigué.
\item Ils (Elles) se sont écrit régulièrement.
\item Anna s'est arrêtée dix minutes.
\item Il a retourné l'omelette.
\end{enumerate}

    \item They saw Paul while crossing the street.
    \item Knowing the truth, she could not stay silent.
    \item He made money selling paintings.
    \item It was a fascinating game.
    \item Having finished the book, he left.
    \item They listen to music while working.
    \item I knit while watching television.

\subsection*{Answers}

\item Sachant la vérité, elle ne pouvait pas rester silencieuse.
\item Il a gagné de l'argent en vendant des tableaux.
